job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The benefits are rather amazing. Matching with the 403(b) plan is twice the amount you put in up to 5% of your salary, giving you a de facto 10% pay increase from your stated salary. The healthcare is incredible in both it's access to superior doctors and facilities, as well as its affordability. I would highly recommend most people with a significant other working in the general area to pick up at job for the University Hospital System just to get the health and dental.
cons: Most staff working in the hospital proper act in a shell-shocked manner, as if they've had to live through some drastic event. This is primarily because of the poor, condescending management at both the middle and upper levels in the Ann Arbor hospital. Ancillary functions such as sanitation, food services, and some lab support functions (especially the IRB) are abysmally run as well, leading to stressful and protracted approval or processing or just a sad working environment overall. Management often seems more concerned with getting their names attached to projects or small incremental improvements than managing well.

job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Perfection is expected. 
Culture and arts in Ann Arbor.
Very affordable HMO for employees. Good about time off and family care time. Strong senior leadership and university seems to be in good fiscal standing. 200% match on first 5% for retirement. The talent and brilliance that comes to campus is jaw dropping. Many days I feel it a privilege to work here.
cons:
Perfection is expected.
Michigan winters and snow days are never called.
Large, and very fragmented organization, so experiences will vary. Middle management untrained for managing people, and it is problematic. Layoffs in a couple areas, attrition in others. Staff is often not being replaced and it is causing heavy workload and stress on those remaining. Univ apparently ignoring this while dumping money into MHealthy program to help keep staff stress down. Raises the last couple years were crummy. Vacation accrual could be better. Parking is expensive and often not close to workplace. Ann Arbor traffic is ridiculous! No quick way to freeways. Increasing pressure on staff to carpool, take bus, or bicycle to work. Less and less accommodation for drivers. Politically, a very active and liberal institution.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student (Biomedical) in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Fantastic place to do graduate research
Top-notch facilities
Fantastic research being done here
Great community but that could depend on the department
Ann Arbor is a good city to live in and feels safe

Not sure if I have hit 20 words, so I am just adding on more words to try and hit it. Not much else to say since your mileage will vary as a graduate student here at the UofM depending on program of interest. For the most part Michigan is a fantastic place to do graduate research
cons:
Ann Arbor is expensive to live in. Most university towns are likely becoming so these days, so this might not be much different from anywhere else. Essentially the slow rate of increase in stipend pay at all Universities and the high rate of increase in rent Nation-wide means we graduate students really feel the squeeze. If you get a room mate you should be able to make it work here however. 

Don't expect to drive your car into the lab/work. As a student you can't purchase the closer parking spots (anywhere in walking distance basically) and even if you could you are contending with staff of the research part of UofM, the teaching staff of UofM, the administrative staff for both and all the doctors and nurses associated with the hospital. Makes for a great dynamic place to do research, but a pain to find parking

pros: I enjoyed the work I did, it kept me very busy and allowed me to learn new processes.  I appreciated the support people who helped me to learn how to navigate through any new programs I was introduced to.  I loved the benefits and the flexible schedule that was available at times.  The paid week off at Christmas was wonderful.
cons: Management knew less about processes than the team but took credit for the hard work you accomplished daily.  Our manager did not know how to fill out a basic form and if a report was requested of them they passed it off to someone else but presented it as their work.  Other people even prepared their presentations for conferences.  How does a clueless person get paid such an enormous salary to know NOTHING but how to send an e-mail, say yes to everything asked of them even if it creates problems for the team and does not have the work experience or knowledge to do said job.

review_title: The University is a very comfortable place to work.
job_title: Web Designer Senior in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The benefits are unbelievable. For example, the University doubles what I put in for my 403-B fund, and my prescription costs are minimal ($7-$21). Vacation time is phenomenal - 2 days per month, and this accumulates. In addition, the University is very generous with sick time, at fifteen days per year. After two years of employment, if an employee needs to take extended medical leave, they have 26 weeks available to do so. I have heard of women using this time after childbirth. In talking about great benefits the University offers, I must mention the tuition support they offer. They basically reimbursed me for half of my tuition to attend graduate school, and were very flexible with my work schedule to accommodate my school schedule. All in all, the as a University employee, you really feel you're being taken care of.
cons: The politics and the snail's pace that things get done can be trying. Because of the University's decentralized nature, each office has its own agenda, and its own internal issues. Therefore, it is hard to make plans and have hard deadlines in place to complete projects. Within my office, the team atmosphere is great, but there is no clear process that we follow, and the structure is vague. It can be hard to keep momentum going due to the culture that's in place, and I often feel like my professional wheels are spinning. It's very comfortable here, but not particularly challenging.

job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: It's part of U-M, so there's good benefits. Last year the school allowed summer flex hours and it's continuing that, so that's a nice touch. Most faculty treat you with respect. My work is centered around students doing great things, so despite how toxic the work environment is, the students keep me motivated.
cons:
The leadership claims to care about equity, inclusion, a healthy work culture, stuff like that, but in reality this isn't the case. If you're staff, you're expendable. If a faculty member or some other superior is unfair to you, there isn't anything you can do about it except find a new place to work. The school recently started a "culture champions" group, but when the the leadership see staff as second class compared to faculty, it doesn't matter. Recent efforts to make UMSN a better place to work are a depressing joke. Staff just aren't valued here which is sad because if the turnover wasn't so high maybe the place would function better.

On top of the head honchos not caring about staff, there is an issue here with trash talking among colleagues. You could hear praise from someone and a few weeks later find out they've been talking trash about you. Very demoralizing.

On top of this, there's no where to park and the old building where most people work has cockroaches. The school as a whole is very disorganized.

job_title: Project Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I get a large number of days off and there is no pressure to work more than 40 hrs per week.  The university matches my 403(b) contribution 1.5 to 1 (yeah, that's right, I put in a buck and they put in a buck fifty).  My boss is great.  He's a former rocket scientist, test engineer, and executive of Boeing and also a Michigan farm boy.  He lets me do my job without micro managing, but he's there for me when I need support.  He has little tolerance for incompetence, but that is not a problem for me.  He is tolerant of mistakes as long as they aren't repeated habitually.
cons: The administrative infrastructure at the University expands on its own momentum.  It is so entrenched that it has a power base as strong as any.  They often complicate processes just to justify their existence.  There's no going around them.  It can be extremely frustrating.  They even protect incompetence (which really frustrates my boss).  The pay is not great for the level of qualifications they expect, but it is the University of Michigan.

review_title: Lectureships at UM: How UofM is a good place to work, but not a very welcoming one
job_title: Leo Lecturer I in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: There are many benefits--everything from the actual benefits (nice retirement matching package, e.g.) to working for an institution that knows what it's doing and has money and has bright students.  Your colleagues are smart and engaged.  The location is nice and convenient; the buses up to North Campus are very helpful in the winter.
cons: UM is such a big school that it has a lot of moving parts.  A lot of jobs, a lot of people, a lot of students.  I don't know if that *results* in their making everyone feel more or less worthless or expendable, but that's ultimately what happens.  We are all made to feel completely disposable, and indeed many are treated as such.  I cannot wait to get out of here--to work for a school or a company in the industry that lets me know I am valued, and that does indeed value me.  Finally, the pay.  I make a little over 30k a year doing what tenured professors do for double, TRIPLE, or QUADRUPLE that.  Way to not value your employees, UM.

pros:

The stess level of working for University of Michigan is kind of low. Usually the project there does not have a tight timeline. I have been there for about 1 year, there has no single time I am pushed by deadline.  If you want a typical 9:00 am to 5:30 pm job, this is for you.
cons:
The pay rate there is pretty low. I have a master degree and many years of job experience, they only offered me a very low pay rate. There is no bonus or any other extra. The pay rate increase is very very low, only around 3% yearly, I think? 
Another downside bothered me is that I do not see a career path there. I have every confidence that I am qualified for a senior develipment position. job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
U-M is a world-class research campus. When I was first hired, I was told that, "You could attend [scientific] seminars for 8 hours a day, every day, almost every week of the year." This is a very vibrant and highly collegial research environment, which has allowed me to thrive as a research fellow. I also work for a boss that gives my a great deal of independence, which has been great for both pushing my research into interesting directions while giving me nice work/life balance.

Outside of my own work environment, the U has a vibrant campus that integrates quite nicely with the city of Ann Arbor. The U also offers great benefits, even to a "lowly" postdoc like myself.
cons:
Because the University of Michigan is a top 10 research institute, there is a definite glass ceiling for postdocs: No postdocs I know have been promoted to assistant professor internally. To become a junior professor here, you have to start your lab elsewhere, prove yourself, and then come back.

While research fellows receive top notch health benefits at U-M, we receive no retirement benefits.

job_title: Non Managerial in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: They had several positions to always keep going up to posted on the board, so you were able to move every six months if you wanted to use a job as a stepping board.
cons: Dictatorship management, and management was often swamped with paper work, so there was not any time to be personable.  Paper work first patients second.  Don't plan on working 20+ years...U of M LOVES to fire older employees, I am assuming the benefits package is too expensive.  Parking is not based on pay, but $1000+ if you want to park on property.

review_title: Can be great; can be a drag--all depends on which department you're talking about.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The University is far too broad and diverse an organization for me to be able to give a single assessment of what it's like. So much depends on which department you're working for, and how favorably the upper brass views your project to be. I can say that my time there was incredibly enlightening. (And yes, I mean that in a good way.)
cons: Have you ever heard the old song that goes "Yeah, UM doesn't pay great, but WOW are the benefits something!" Well... as the years progressed, the benefits seemed to get more and more lackluster. And further, one department I could name has been letting long-time employees go, with the intent of hiring them back as freelancers. In other words, wholly benefits-free.

review_title: If you're in Michigan, this is the place to be
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The University of Michigan has a lot to offer, and is by far the best and most stable employer in southeast Michigan, especially at this time. It employs some of the smartest in the state, and offers exciting jobs doing work you love, along with many opportunities for professional growth and career development, both through internal and external funding sources. If you are involved in research, you get to work with and collaborate with some of the most respected scientists in the world. While experiences may vary wildly based on department and supervisors, it is possibly to create a perfect niche for yourself in terms of research interest, quality of mentorship, and work-life balance.
cons: Compared to similar jobs in non-academic industry, the pay is pretty lousy (although is comparable to the pay at similar institutions). The benefits package is excellent, although for research fellows funded on their own grants, the 'reward' for having outside funding is no access to the terrific retirement plan offered to other employees, as well as limited access to other non-medical benefits.

review_title: Working at the School of Public Health
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: UM, in general, offers excellent benefits and vacation/sick leave. Working with students at the grad school level was easily the best part of the job.
cons: If you are not faculty, especially senior faculty, you are subordinate no matter what kind of experience you may bring as a staff member. Faculty often do not have any management experience and therefore many behave unprofessionally and even unethically. Unfortunately the HR system is a complete charade of any sort of support. If you bring a grievance against a tenured faculty member, you will never win. UM HR's main priority is to protect the U. In many cases, beyond my own experience, people have been horribly mistreated and yet, most behavior goes undisciplined or not even addressed. The School of Public Health is certainly one of the schools at UM that maintains unprofessional and, at times, litigious employeer to employee practices.

job_title: Dining Worker in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Its a dining hall; its easy money, you just walk in and supply manual labor for a couple hours. You can choose your own hours. Can be friendly/relaxed with the workers there. You can zone out and still do a good job. Management is reasonable with conflicts and is even forgiving for being late somewhat routinely. You can become a coordinator for for $9.60/hr or a coordinator for $12/hr, probably not worth it to be honest.
cons: Its a dining hall; its meticulous and boring work. Its not intellectually challenging and your brain will be dulled by the end. You will be working weekends and probably nights, which can be late if they're understaffed (usually). Does not provide much career improvement and means little on a resume besides showing you can work. You can honestly do better than a dining hall, which doesn't say much for me.

review_title: Physics graduate program was a great experience (GSI / GSRA)
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Benefits were amazing, and in particular the health insurance and local health system are awesome (especially for families). I can't believe the amount of amazing care my family received that was _completely_ covered.

The program gives ample training, mentorship, and funding opportunities. I was able to fund myself with teaching partially or fully over many semesters as needed, moving from more "canned" teaching labs to other opportunities over time, even helping with course development one semester - an extremely rewarding experience. Note that Applied Physics does NOT have the same system of funding; I can only speak for the standard Physics program.

Obviously one's experience will vary with advisor, etc., but I was extremely happy with my experience.
cons:
You have to be willing to seek out help when you need it! Graduate school is incredibly stressful and often bewildering, but there are lots of resources available.

And, of course, your experience will only ever be as good as your advisor. Speak to all their students, and if possible, former students who switched advisors. Ask the hard questions. It's the most important decision you will make.

review_title: The University of Michigan is a great place to work and I would (and have) recommended it to friends and family.

pros: Compensation and benefits.  My salary has increased by over 50% in 5 years through promotions and raises.  The benefits are extraordinary.  The University kicks in two dollars for every dollar the employee puts in for retirement.  I contribute five percent, but I get fifteen percent.  I have a large amount of autonomy in my managerial role.
cons: I feel very distant from senior management and the decisions that are made.

job_title: Writing Center Consultant in Dearborn, MI
pros: Flexible Schedule, great people to work with, very encouraging and helpful work enviornemnt that prompts you to grow along with your peers.
cons:
The bureaucracy of the University does not seem to value the Writing Center as much as they should and as a result, support isn't where it should be. 

--Troublesome students who try to abuse the system in place and the students whom the education system utterly failed. They unfortunately wander into the Writing Center with help on an essay or writing assignment, and the level of assistance they need is beyond what the Writing Center can provide, so it's an unfortunate sight and grim reminder of the failings of our education system.

--Some people are seniors, on the eve of graduating, who can't put a proper paragraph together.

--It is a work study job for University students only, so its a bit unfortunate that working there cannot continue past graduation, but it is what it is

review_title: Student Affairs spends too much time "thinking" and not enough time "acting".
job_title: Program Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: good benefits, nice campus, close to many amenities. good people. almost any restaurant delivers to campus. excellent raises if you stay and move up in the ranks. the bureaucracy is limited and actually helpful! you will get support from higher ups. the programs for work/life are amazing!
cons: Student Affairs spends more time thinking and posturing and talking about social justice than actually providing it or working towards it. When told of insidious problems with racism, classism and sexism - people turn away and find excuses for the behavior instead of actually addressing the issue or concern. Upper management in DSA seem to be focused more on the ranks, the appearance and "who's in charge" than actually getting anything done. everyone in the upper levels seems to be more focused on building their careers and their names than doing good.

review_title: Good place to work as a student
job_title: Office Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I worked for UM as a student in a work-study job.  As compared to non-university student part-time jobs, I thought that UM paid very well.  They're very supportive about giving student employees the necessary time off to study during finals.  There are a diverse range of jobs available since it's such a huge university, so it's not hard to find a position that will offer relevant experience and/or transferable skills.
cons: For student employees, including non work-study students, there is typically a limit to the number of hours you can work per week.  This is to try and ensure that all students who want jobs are able to get employment.  If you need more hours, you may find yourself having to seek out an additional job, and trying to schedule two jobs plus class can get difficult.

job_title: Recruiting Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I really love the management there. The staff care a great deal about providing quality assistance to prospective students. They answer questions and guide students even when they may not be interested in going to the University of Michigan for graduate school. I've had the opportunity to choose my level of engagement with the recruiting activities and thus have learned a lot about recruitment and admissions given my exposure.
cons: The University does not pay as well as industry which is not uncommon for universities. However, there are so many opportunities to learn and it is a good place to work if you are interested in using university resources to further your education.

review_title: Never had a chance to get off the ground
job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The small staff meant that the data management responsibilities had to fall onto the intern - great experience there learning excel and access.
cons:
I was their intern for a year and a half, having continued during the school year after my summer internship would have ended. I was hesitant to stay on during the school year year but agreed to for the opportunity to get more involved in the outreach and business development side that I hadn't been able to get exposed to during the summer. Instead of having that chance during the school year, however, I spent the rest of the year doing data management, even though I had a stated interest in getting more involved in the client side. Was definitely disappointed with the opportunities for growth and exposure they afforded me. 

Intern was definitely placed on the wrong side of the "business-administrative divide".

review_title: The work is challenging, intellectually rewarding and inspiring, despite the unsupportive environment & unequal status.
job_title: Lecturer II in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Collaboration opportunities and resources at UM are excellent if you seek them out aggressively.
cons: Advancement opportunities and professional development are limited; teaching salary for same work is less than half of a tenure-track employee. Benefits are less than equal to that of tenure-track employees or administrative staff. Review standards for non-tenure and tenure track are unequal, with a heavier burden of proof placed upon the former to show consistently high levels of expertise and excellence in performing similar tasks.

job_title: Fire Alarm Electrician in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Above average pay, excellent healthcare and retirement benefits.  Recession-proof employer
cons:
Due to above Pro's, UM is typically a terminal employer (virtually no one leaves except via retirement).  The result is akin to a large bucket half full of mice, where all of them scrambling to get to the top, with no regards for who they are stepping on.

Management is typically incompetent, and the bureaucracy typical of government-type employers leaves almost every person on an administrative or managerial position attempting to carve out their own respective niches, or fiefdoms, that they can use to justify their own existence.  

I would leave in a heartbeat if I could find the right situation where I'm actually challenged, and could make enough to offset the lower-tier fringe benefits at other organizations.

review_title: It's a beast, with a potential for beauty.
job_title: Associate Professor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Money and resources.  The university has an abundance of resources and talent.
cons: The University of Michigan is a very large.  I have no doubt that the satisfaction of one's employment varies greatly from department to department.  The University is a top-tier institution - one of the very best public institutions in the country - but this distinction also creates a sense of elitism.  You hear phrases like "The Michigan way," and that may be translated to mean "We're better than everybody else."  That attitude certainly exemplifies the University's lack of cooperation with other universities in the state of Michigan, and it leads to an insular environment that is somewhat stiflled by breathing only its own air.  Lighten up, UM.  There's a whole world out there that you could benefit from if you'd only be more receptive.

job_title: Project Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great benefits, some funds for professional development, flexible schedule and in general, got to work on projects that seemed to make a difference in people's lives.
cons: Total bureaucracy. School of Public Health pays it's project managers way lower than what is standard, even lower than project managers in other schools within the University. Yearly pay increases were minimal and it takes years and a lot of self-advocacy to get bumped into the next pay-grade. You are typically working under a faculty member who often doesn't have a lot of time to dedicate to the projects so you are often on your own. Faculty have a lot of power so there is a lot of favoritism to contend with.

job_title: Marketing Communications Specialist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I worked for two departments, and both of them had a close-knit feel. I got to know my coworkers well and everyone was friendly and welcoming. The University hosts several forums a year for all communications staff, and that was helpful in understanding how my departments fit in with the University as a whole. The majority of staff that I met were not part of academic families, so if you are someone who is married to an academic, you will be one of the few. This can actually be a benefit on your part as you can see things from the academic point of view, whereas others cannot.
cons:
The winters are extremely cold, but at least the staff get snow days now!
The parking is expensive.
Job security is a double-edged sword. On one hand, you don't have to be looking over your shoulder worrying about lay-offs. On the other hand, there are some staff members who seem to have given up, and they just stick around.

review_title: A top university that's a great place for faculty and students, but average at best for staff
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
- You work with really smart, very hard-working people who are dedicated to public education, driven by the mission
- UM offers strong benefits and above average professional development
- Except at the highest levels, staff have no voice
cons: Top levels of leadership have proliferated salary and administrative job growth to excess at the highest levels while salary growth for all other staff doesn't keep up with the cost of living increases and it's extremely difficult to get approval for new positions in the operational departments that serve students.

review_title: Ok to work for, but not for too long.
job_title: Project Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Ok to work for, but not for too long. After 3 years, you’ll find your skills-gap has widened and it’s even more difficult to find a job elsewhere. Good benefits, but the cost of not learning as an employee is too high. Join at the end of your career, definitely not at the start.
cons: No incentives to reduce waste or increase quality. Training is almost non-existent so nothing is learned other then via your own self motivation to seek training from outside sources and then apply it to your daily work. Quality defects everywhere and the majority of employees don’t care. My team was given a raise after receiving approval from management and HR, but after paying it for months, they reduced our salaries cause 1 person in the bureaucracy didn’t give their approval. The approval process apparently changed but no one knew, not even HR. Extremely poor change management.

job_title: PhD Candidate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Ann Arbor attracts intelligent kind people that are in a top-10 program of any field. The biomedical science PhD programs specifically are managed well and have hundreds of faculty to work with. I have been mentored extremely well and published multiple times during my PhD. Many professors have great connections in academia and industry and there are many opportunities for learning about alternative careers.
cons: Not a big fan of the winters here but that is minor. While there are a lot of faculty, like anywhere, there are a lot of poor mentors that should be avoided. World-class researchers are here, but it can take some effort to find them and join their labs.

job_title: Researcher in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Funding, Prestige of working for the U of M brand, Benefits
cons: Minimal room for advancement, Abysmal compensation, Disrespectful of employees (unless you have an MD or PhD), HR and its policies restrict success at the university, High turnover (which gives more work to those left behind), Lack of standardization across departments in health system leads to confusion and chaos (especially when it comes to job title assignments), No benefit to being a "loyal" employee (those who stay get paid less than those just hired in)

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I really enjoyed my co-workers and the research being performed at UMich. Very dedicated and friendly co-workers. Nice research facilities on campus.
cons: No raise during my 3 years at UMich. My advisor showered me with kind words regarding my contributions to the group, but this was never translated into a raise in pay. UMich was my second postdoc institution (moved here due to my husband accepting a tenure track position in Michigan). I was previously funded by an NIH T32 grant at UPenn and had received annual raises, so I was very disappointed with my appointment at UMich! I began applying for tenure track faculty positions, but my boss failed to send his letters of recommendation. After this, I found a job in the pharmaceutical industry and finally have work/life balance! Best decision of my life.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The University of Michigan is a wonderful place to work. The students are very motivated, and it is refreshing to work for an institution that cares so much for the people they serve. I was also pleasantly surprised by the excellent benefits package and professional development opportunities. Overall, an excellent place to work and start your career.
cons: The only downside, to me, is how much movement there is in entry to mid-level positions. Many people in higher level positions stay at the U-M for a long time, likely because of the supportive community and benefits, so this doesn't leave a lot of room for upward mobility, especially if you are new to higher education/academics. This can be especially challenging for a young professional who wants to stay at U-M for a long time because it may take a several years to move up in the institution.

review_title: Great benefits, great coworkers, leadership is hit or miss.
job_title: Communications Project Manager for A University Program in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: My department had fantastic, competent staff and was a warm and welcoming environment. Good management and coaching, some opportunities to be creative. The University offers great benefits, has good training programs.
cons:
Of course, fundraising is a priority. Folks on the development side would pop in seemingly sporadically for anything that might impact funding, and improvements could be made to approach this more strategically.

I had limited interaction with higher-level leadership and the greater administration, but when there were any potential conflicts, they seemed to take a "clamp down" approach with little rationale provided for us peons on the lower rungs. This led to some distrust and seemed to increase the disconnect between our department and broader leadership.

review_title: Great place to learn, limited collaborative thinking
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The stature of a world class university is helpful to build skills and create new things.  The support for learning is high.  There is improving infrastructure for better management, great benefits in spite of cutbacks, and good employee support programs.
cons: UM tends to be insular, silo-ed, territorial due to decentralization and traditional corporate thinking, enabled by big corporate consulting in certain sectors.  Innovation can be limited to some of the best and brightest faculty. There is a tendency to keep people in classification boxes, so that creatives or innovative staff either leave or are shown the door, connected to ageism, cutbacks , low salaries or managers who become threatened as you gain in ability.

job_title: Sys. Admin. in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
1. Outstanding benefits; not just medical, but the social benefits including the wealth of discounts with area businesses, low-cost recreation facilities, and a safe campus.
2. The collaboration between the different staff departments (at least in the technology area...).
3. The low risk of being laid-off.
cons:
1. PARKING!!!!!!!! I'm blessed to have two large structures next to my building, but trying to find something in the middle of the day is close to impossible.
2. STUDENTS!!!!! Most are great people, the big headache comes when you approach an intersection in your car on Central Campus in the middle of the day. There are few traffic lights to help with pedestrian crossing, so students commonly walk in front of traffic to cross the street. Combine that with the parking problem and you may as well just walk to where you need to be.

review_title: Secure, but slow to move up
job_title: Secretary in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Very few layoffs, good benefits, good sick time and vacation time, tons of other jobs to apply to, interesting people, did I mention you won't get fired... Even if you suck they will just shuffle you to another department
cons: Impossible to get another job for years, time in UM is always considered before ability, lied to about raise potential (2% or less per year, there are no real raises based on your performance, everyone gets the same raise no matter how hard they work), lazy people cannot be fired-it's like a union!, takes forever to get things done through red tape paperwork,

job_title: Athletics (Full-Time) in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
-Great benefits.
-A handful of intelligent, forward-thinking co-workers.
cons:
-No real room for growth (HR doesn't even have a plan).
-HR appears to be more concerned with winning awards than creating a positive work environment.
-Difficult to work with different departments; everybody's out for themselves.
-Most employees do everything they can to avoid positive change - would rather keep doing things like they've been done forever.
-Dept. likes to talk about how awesome we are, how great of a place to work this is, how we're "the leaders and best," but that couldn't be further from the truth. Athletics is littered with small people with big egos who've been working here way too long. They hinder any and all progress. I've been a part of several pro sports organizations - this staff doesn't stack up.
-Don't even get me started on the exploitation of "student"-athletes.

job_title: Cook in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I absolutely love working for the University of Michigan. They have great benefits and they make it hard to leave. In my job hunts I really only look at transferring to a different location at the University. Highest paying cook position I've ever seen. It's also very constant and secure because the Union is extremely active for employees
cons: Management is not great. Some of them are very arrogant, but I work in a kitchen and you kind of expect that with chefs. It can be very difficult to get the schedule you want. But the pay is all negotiated by a Union, which can be both a good and a bad thing I guess. Highest paying cook position I've ever seen.

review_title: Great for the resume, unpleasant work environment
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: A great school, will look great on your resume.
cons: If you are a graduate student you will be expected to produce results.  In science that is not always possible immediately due to a number of technical difficulties as well as difficulties encountered due to individual projects.  The PI may be so far removed from doing lab bench work that they have forgotten the reality of how difficult it is to get your experiments to work.  Also right now, most PI's are struggling to get grants so they need the data to keep the lab open.  They often transfer that stress to you since you are the one they are using to get the data.

job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Germantown, WI
pros: UM provides amazing benefits and has a large infrastructure to support academic research. UM is open to working with private companies, especially when it comes to funding from those companies. This approach does help with the difficulties in obtaining outside funding.
cons: UM is still in the publish or perish mindset and that presents issues with those individuals on the research track (research investigator, assistant research scientist, etc). While they have the ability to apply for grants, a lot more focus is on advancing the careers of MD scientists that want to pursue research, as compared to those with a PhD degree.

review_title: Makes it really difficult for research staff to succeed
job_title: Research Lab Technician in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Its a good and reputed institution.

Insurance and benefits are decent.
cons:
Their HR is ill equipped with handling anything and is a joke. Delays are to be always expected. If you raise some concerns against a faculty or the institution for unfair practices, you are going to have a terrible time!

Research staff never get any opportunities to grow. They are paid way lower than other institutions of lower funding and repute. They make strict rules for for RIF and yearly raises, that ensures that you keep earning next to nothing.

They love to take advantage and exploit international workers.

job_title: GSRA in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great benefits that are pretty much free.  I am now making almost twice as much as a post doc at another school but am at the same standard of living as I had in AA due to higher cost of living here and paying much more for healthcare.  The school rocks.  So many great opportunities to work with the best of the best researchers in all fields.  Highly collaborative environment.  Tons of resources.  CSCAR.  Parental leave. There's a great GSI union (GEO) which has fought to improve pay and benefits for all grad students.Dissertation format facilitates getting papers published.  Ann Arbor is a great little town with fantastic food.
cons: Weather sucks in the winter (awesome in the summer though).  High expectations from advisors.  Pay is low but standard for a grad student stipend.

review_title: Working at UofM is really productive and helps to advance in career.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: U of M is full of talented people from different countries and is truly international in every aspect with very high standards. The research at U of M is of high standards and is well funded too. Its a nice place to do post doctoral research at U of M.
cons: The only downside at the U of M is the whether in the locality. The winters are horrible and if you are from a tropical country this place might frighten you..! The other issue is the cost of living in Ann Arbor is more than what you expect for this kind of a small town.

review_title: Undergrad/grad part time jobs are a great solution
job_title: Grader I in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I got both my graduate and undergraduate degrees from Michigan, and had experience working part-time jobs during both. I worked as a homework grader for the Mathematics department as well as for the School of Information. There's great flexibility in picking your hours. I found these jobs to be a great opportunity to get close to professors... Wonderful for reference letters!
cons: The hours for grading tend to be small: think 5-10 per week. That can be a detractor to some folks looking for more consistent work to support tuition and fees. It can be difficult to find these jobs: in some instances (math) you must be  a student in that department, and you should have taken the class and had one of the top performances out of all the students. There's a high standard.

job_title: Research Associate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Very motivated, very smart and capable team.  We would have team meetings about once per week do discuss what needed to get done regarding the upcoming project and then we would go off to complete our individual tasks - there was very little supervision - a good thing in my opinion.
cons: As stated in the pros section - there was very little supervision, so if this is something you prefer to have then this would be a difficult place to work since there was a large hands off attitude.

job_title: Research Associate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: U of M is a wonderful University to work for.  Like with any company or job, WHO you work for is important.  The benefits are great because you have their top ranked hospital that provides health care. Their retirement plan is like no other!   I only worked in the biological science department and have seen everything from awesome bosses to poor bosses.
cons: Salary is not as competitive as in the industry.  In biological sciences, some of the work environments are terrible and needs to be monitored more by the higher ups.  Notorious for taking advantage of cheap labor (research associates).  Unfortunately, there's nothing like that in place because it's academia.

job_title: Clinical Subjects Associate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I've found the atmosphere at U of M to be very inclusive and tolerant of all people's individual dispositions, as well as lifestyles. One of the most progressive places I've ever worked, and very research-oriented. Facilities are constantly being updated as we receive large endowments every year. Great place to attend and work. In my pay range for being single with no dependents, I receive my healthcare and very basic dental at no cost to myself. When I was part time it was not included, but as a full time employee it became a great perk.
cons: Parking is usually pretty terrible despite the university's efforts to be more accommodating. It's the city setting that both helps (paid street parking) and hinders (very limited lots available, high parking costs out of pocket) that aspect.

review_title: It all depends on your department and your goals
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Heath benefits are great! You have flexibility in most scenarios. There are so many interesting things happening on campus that can serve as balance and/or inspiration. There is a push for collaboration across department which is a valuable learning experience.
cons: Some many interesting opportunities and flexibility can make it challenging to focus. Professional advice is not always aligned with the realities of the job market. Despite the push for projects that involve collaboration across departments there is not currently a great culture to support that. A lot of people involved don't know how to collaborate effectively and often the University has incentives in place that are at cross purposes.

job_title: Systems Administrator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Great place to tune your IT skills
Chance to work on solving unique IT research/collaboration challenges.
Flexibility to experiment and try new technologies.
Great time off compensation.
cons:
Pay is lower then private sector, and low merit increases.
Politics tend to drive management decisions and not best practice.  I know this can be true in most work places but at a large university this is greatly amplified.  This can get frustrating when IT decisions are made that are clearly politically driven.

job_title: Plant Operations in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Pay and Benefits (that cost a large percentage of your pay)
cons: Management, Human Resources, dislike of all employees that support the university, lack of respect, arrogance of management, duplicity in their treatment of employees based on their job positions, lack of growth potential, and a wasteful attitude in all aspects of the operation of the university except when employee wages and benefits are concerned - I have worked here over 8 years and each year I take home less than the prior year!

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
A very prestigious school with great programs. Almost every department is rank among the top in the nation.
The university is one of the founding members (1900) of the Association of American Universities, the nation's most significant consortium of research universities. The university manages one of the largest annual collegiate research budgets of any university in the United States, totaling about US $775 million per annum from 2004 to 2005, and US $797 million in 2006, and $823 million as of year end 2007. The Medical School spent the most at over US $333 million, while the College of Engineering was second at more than $131 million.UM also has a technology transfer office, which is the university conduit between laboratory research and corporate commercialization interests.
cons: Extreme temperature variation in ann arbor a big minus.

review_title: Great benefits, management style leaves much to be desired
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Flexibility
Benefits
Retirement match
Able to use annual leave without many questions from upper management (although campus should get on page with the health system and switch to a PTO format)
cons:
Micromanagement approach from overseeing units (I.e. Office of Research, or UMOR)
Opportunities are limited for administrative staff
Low compensation compared to corporate
As mentioned above, a switch to the PTO system versus vacation/sick would allow more flexibility on how time off is used.

review_title: being a grad student is tough, and gets you through
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Best is you walk out with a degree with little chance of failure. You have a lot of smart people to interact with every day, and lots of people willing to help you at every step of education. You also get a ton of family benefits for health care, dental care, prescriptions, and life insurance. You get benefits for each child you have, and there are great family housing options.
cons: Long hours, low pay, pay does not reflect hard work, and there is almost no chance of a raise. The living costs downtown rival those of downtown San Francisco, so you may want to get a place a little ways from campus.

review_title: Great place to work; balance with family life
job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The benefits and the culture are the highlights.  5 weeks of vacation + 2 weeks of standard padi time off (4th of July, Memorial Day, etc) + up to 3 weeks of sick time per year.  Great health plans and retirement benefits too.  Culture is down-to-earth professionals who want to make a difference in the world.
cons: Highly decentralized bureaucracy can make some administrative processes unnecessarily complicated; also creating some inefficiencies in the overall organization.  Cycle of busy/not-so-busy time corresponds with school year and is also something to be aware of.

review_title: Online learning environment Operations Infrastructure Architect
job_title: Operations Infrastructure Architect in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
generous vacation (5 weeks per year + 1 week off between Christmas and New Years days)

10% 403b of salary match for 5% employee contribution

generous health care benefits
cons:
no technical career track so hard to advance

employees don't leave, so advancement constrained by incumbency

Ann Arbor is a fairly small town with few other options for certain high-skill level jobs

University pay is lower than private industry, but lack of skilled people in MI makes applicant pool smaller every year

lot of older employees means hard to make organizational changes, especially those requiring technology

job_title: Senior Business Process Consultant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Fantastic, healthy workplace culture, increasingly flexible work schedules, constantly innovating, and lots of fun!

Definitely the healthiest workplace culture I've ever experienced - staff at all levels are encouraged to raise problems or concerns and they are taken seriously. Staff at all levels have many tools to gather data around the problem and propose a business case to make change.  Lots of emphasis on coaching and professional development - and this is also funded!
cons: Work schedules for salaried employees were somewhat inflexible, but this is quickly changing. (e..g. "flexible" defined as choosing your own start/end time but it had to be the same start & end 5 days a week; can only work from home up to 1 day per week; option to do 4 10's without ability to work from home)

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: It's a large and diverse university where you get to meet people of all kinds of background and try out many new things. And it's peaceful which is conducive to keeping your head down to the book. Also the goods around here are cheap.
cons: It's sort of isolated. Two years in you will miss the loud and fast-paced life in a big city. There aren't a lot of entertainments around here. Although goods by and large are cheaper than those in a big city, the options are quite limited. Also many people in here have midwest mentality - friendly on the surface but often times very close-minded or even ignorant.

review_title: Fine for a student job, but don't expect to stay there
job_title: Media Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Lots of resources, generally a good atmosphere, some fun work. It's a great school and you'll work with some very cool people.
cons: The school is too big. No matter what department you work in, there are all kinds of issues with cross-departmental communication (or lack thereof), and lots of hoops to jump through if you want to get anything done. The most discouraging part though is that student workers (at least where I worked) get a raw deal. We ended up with not as many hours as promised, poor management that didn't communicate well, and motivated performance wasn't rewarded. You can try to go above and beyond, but it won't get you anywhere and there's essentially no chance for upward movement or pay raises.

job_title: Student Caller in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Telefund allows flexible schedule for students, and it pays pretty well, considering how easy the job is. Plus, it was fun to work with other students--I made a lot of friends when I worked there. 

Mostly, this is a decent part-time job for college students hoping to earn a little extra money for a semester or two, but some of the student managers who worked there back in my day have gone on to work in fundraising/development elsewhere.
cons: At least when I worked there, they were pretty rigid about things like not doing homework on shift and sticking to the ask ladder (which could be a little stressful with some alumni).

job_title: Research Technician Associate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Well, it's UM. It looks good on paper, has great research going for it, lots of great PI/labs to collaborate with, and some fancy new facilities.
cons: Money. My initial offer was $28k - I have my bachelor's degree and 5 years experience (1 year as a manager) in this field. I negotiated up a bit, but still not a good rate for someone with a college degree (and student loans). They also expect a lot out of you - working outside the 8 hour work days, on weekends, etc. without overtime pay.

job_title: CUSTODIAN II in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Camaraderie, good union position and pay, excellent university, lovely locations are all to be found working in Housing for the University of Michigan.  Working currently as a full-time temporary employee, so not subject to union rules/pay, but I have a good view of those who are within the union.
cons: An occasional lack of communication between the staff and management.  Sometimes spread thinly, especially in the beginning.  Once a rhythm is found between the day-to-day and those special tasks, life at Housing becomes a lot easier.  Having a good working relationship with one's boss really helps as well.

review_title: Reasonable experience for future post-secondary educators
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Great community around the university; strong grad student union; strong organizations within the department to help prepare students for educational or industry jobs after dissertation.
Department is supportive of taking classes with the school of education, which I have heard is rare at places like UofM
cons:
Work expectations are intense.  It's not out of the norm for graduate programs, but still something to be aware of. 60+ hrs a week is not uncommon.

While the department is supportive of taking education classes, there are few opportunities to do more than GSI (TA) for courses.

Salaries are low for the area, makes it hard to find a decent apartment near work.

job_title: Tutor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: It is one of the best university in US, isn't it?? My job is a student tutor. But i learned a lot, like how to communicate with others, and thus improved my interpersonal skills a lot. The working environment is not that fast-paced. I like it when I can help other students in math and statistics.
cons: The  payment is not that high. Only 9 dollars per hour. Even lower than working in student dining hall, which is about 10 dollars per hour. If I worked as a tutor for an off-campus employer, it would be 20 dollars per hour, which is pretty good.

job_title: Web Applications Developer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: They was a fair amount flexibility with the amount of time worked and the days on which I was allowed to work. The work environment was laid-back and the people were generally friendly. As a super part-time working directly for a small department, I received no benefits beyond my pay, which was on the low end of reasonable.
cons: The staff that hired me, who were also my direct superiors, had no previous experience with hiring or managing personnel. I spent a lot of time sitting on my hands because my boss had no work for me when I came in. In the end, I left because there were more important things to spend my time on.

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Freedom to develop my course and teach it as I wish. Teaching here is impressive so this experience has opened doors for me. Secretarial support for printing is excellent, IT support is excellent, Physical environment in classroom is very good.
cons: U of M has not taken a strong stand against racist incidents on campus this year leading to a toxic atmosphere.  Lecturers are not valued by U of M; we are treated as if we are disposable commodities even though we perform at an exceptional level.

job_title: Applications Systems Programmer/Analyst in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Benefits are great compared to many companies. The University doubles your contribution to a 403a (up to 10%), so I pay 5% of my pay to it and they pay twice that. Medical, dental, and vision benefits are all pretty good. Being a part of the University is great; there are tons of restaurants around town and the Ann Arbor atmosphere is vibrant.
cons: Pay is low. Furthermore, pay for some departments is wildly different from other departments. In one case, an ex co-worker of mine received a job offer for a lower-responsibility job with another department with 30% more pay.

review_title: Great place to work, for most.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great health insurance coverage, and overall benefit plan.  Surrounded by a lot of smart people, who genuinely care about students.
cons: Downside to all the smart people, is that they don't realize how much they don't know. Tough place to be if you're a lower-level staff member, as UM has a pretty intractable hierarchy, with tenured faculty at the top, looking down on those who do the actual work.

review_title: a good place to work, especially if you are a mom
job_title: Research Associate Intermediate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Good benefits and plenty of paid off time so you can care your family; good environment, nice offices, sweet people (usually less aggressive than people work in companies, I think) to work with. You can find a lot of reasons to love your job even if your job itself is not fun.
cons: Does not pay very well; you can barely pay for 2 kids' day care if you want them to go to a not bad day care center. Sometimes, you wish people can work harder and take their jobs more seriously like you do, rather than thinking it's a school job, not a job in the real world.

review_title: Great place to be a graduate student - although, depends on your advisor
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: My advisor allowed very flexible hours and even extended vacation time for international students to travel back to their home countries.  The benefits from the University are great.  The health care covers about everything and the vision and dental are reasonably priced.  There's also a child-care subsidy (~$5500/year/kid) for them to attend daycare if both parents work/are full-time students.
cons: Depends on the advisor.  However, graduate school is hard.  Talk with other graduate students to see if your situtation is reasonable.  If not - switch to a different advisor.  Spending in extra year to get a PhD in a happy (but stressful) environment is better than spending 4-5 years unhappy.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The benefits, the mission of the university. I had access to a lot of cultural and sporting events that I would not have otherwise because of where I worked.
cons: No opportunity for advancement. I worked in a small school so I really could only make lateral moves, not vertical. Not a great place for a younger person to work. Most people that work at the University seem to be closer to retirement age than not, so I think that it is a hard place for young professionals to work.

review_title: Good benefits but slow lateral movement without moving around to other departments
job_title: Computer Technician in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
They hire internally first, so once you're in, it is a lot easier to move around to other departments in the University. This is nice because you can move laterally but not really ever have to worry about moving to another city. 
Lots of opportunities
Good benefits
You always know what other people are paid because it is freely available information (it is government). This is kind of nice because you can always see if you are aptly compensated.
cons:
Some departments move really slowly so it can be hard to move laterally 
Some people have positions and really don't know what they are doing. Unfortunately, it seems that there are a lot of people like this in management positions.

review_title: Fantastic environment, opportunity and career potential -- runied by tenured bosses.
job_title: Research Technician Intermediate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
-Unbeatable benefits
-Nice Location
-Prestige (if you're into that stuff)
-Good pay for a fresh-out-of-college job
-Possibility of being published in a paper
cons:
-Academic hierarchy. If you don't have a masters or above, you might as well be a high school drop out in their eyes.
-Elitists. They all think they are better than you.
-Tenured bosses. They WILL treat you like garbage, harass you, verbally abuse you, etc. and HR has zero power to help you out.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Pay is great for a graduate student. The department is renowned and brings in great resources for Ph.D. students to develop. In addition to faculty, there are many research scientists that help drive projects forward and provide valuable mentorship to Ph.D. students.
cons: Many research groups are large, which can cause individuals to fall through the cracks and be less closely monitored by their PI/supervisor.  While autonomy is a necessary part of graduate school, an advisor's lack of familiarity with one's work can impede progress toward degree completion.

job_title: Project Manager Associate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Benefits package is extremely competitive. 401K Matching program was better than I have seen anywhere else so far.
cons: If you need to drive to your office in Ann Arbor the parking is a daily pain. You either pay $600 a year for a parking pass for the lots closest to the buildings or you can pay less to park far out and then take a bus to your office. There are a few other options depending on the location of the office you work at but overall there is no nice or cheap/free/easy way to park. It gets old having to spend money and dealing with hunting for a spot everyday to get to a place that you are working to make money.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: It would be a great place to work with decent management.
cons: Staff morale is bad in Med School Administration. The current management and leadership is the worst I've ever worked for. There's an inexcusable lack of fairness, appreciation, and respect for staff. Among other weirdness, there's a very disturbing trend where people with no experience get the best career opportunities and promotions, creating bad feelings and hurting unity. The Dean's Office is a disaster - it's hard to tell who, if anyone, is in charge there and the normal rules, policies, and conduct are routinely ignored or overruled. It's like the Wild West. Stay away.

review_title: For students looking for a part time job, look here (in any of the many departments)
job_title: Intramural Referee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: There's plenty to do part-time as a student (which is my perspective). The hours are flexible so you can work as much or as little as you need/can. You can make plenty of connections either with professors when doing research or learning valuable skills such as teamwork and conflict resolution by working with the IM Sports department. Numerous opportunities to enhance college experience.
cons: The job I held was minimum wage to start so don't expect a lot in payment. Still, you could do much worse.

job_title: Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Depends on your exact project for the most part, though the university does a great job of helping you with navigating the bureaucracy and the range of opportunities available. If you're willing to put in the work to find a good project, go for it!
cons: Again, depends mainly on your project and specific supervisor. The university is massive and in spite of their best efforts, the bureaucracy can be frustrating. For research assistants, expect low pay with little opportunity for advancement.

job_title: IOS Developer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: You get to see some amazing 3D technology including the UM Den, 3D printing, 3D scanners, and novel holographic techniques. The best part of my job was programming basic AI scripts for the game I was working on.
cons: Some of the coding is busy work, such as assembling assets or menu systems. The projects were semi-complicated and would take a lot of time to finish completely. Lots of testing was required to flush out bugs without the use of a test suit and sometimes I'd find myself returning to a project I thought I completed months ago in order to fix a newly discovered bug.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: My supervisors  are interested in my personal and professional development and encourage me to go the extra mile and trust my own judgement.  Their words to me at a recent review: "We've got your back."  You don't often hear that from a supervisor.  Great team and wonderful attitudes around the department of always helping each other, there's no such thing as a dumb question and the understanding that life happens and personal life can sometimes require working adjustments.
cons: Limited pay increase potential.

job_title: Clinical Research Project Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Pros are: 
-benefits
-can be work/life balance
-location is good if you are in the surrounding area
-opportunity to move within departments/organization pretty easily
cons:
Cons are: 
-very top heavy leadership
-as a project manager, I have little to no resources to complete my job and have no guidance from my manager who has to no leadership herself
-low salary
-very difficult to fire anyone, so the morale is low - why work harder than anyone else? 
-no mentorship for physicians or staff doing research
-nonsensical job titles/salary ranges for people doing very different work but are under the same title and lack of advancement available for them

review_title: Friendly and cooperative admin. and extremely smart colleagues
job_title: Researcher in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
- Great town
- Above Mid. west avg. compensation 
- Work at the cutting edge of science and tech.
- Encouraging and friendly atmosphere.
- Housing facilities on and off campus are one of the best in US.
- University backs , at least Engineering and Medical departments, with substantial funding and support.
- Expanding rapidly and investing in emerging tech. like environmental, medical and IT.
- Brings a lot of top companies to campus, can be a major help in gaining a job at a top industry player.
cons:
- Workload is very high. You will be spending days and sometimes nights in the lab working on problems.
- Some people might not like the weather but you get all 4 seasons.

review_title: UofM Exhibit Museum gave me relevant experience and skills for my future career as an educator.
job_title: Museum Docent (Student Work-Study) in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Working at the museum was more than just another campus job.  I got training and experience that helped me prepare for my future career as a teacher.  I was trusted with leadership opportunities, such as work in the museum store, scheduling in the museum office, and acting as Staff-In-Charge on the weekends.  The museum team treated me like a young professional, while also respecting my priorities as a student.
cons: I loved my time working at the museum.  But, if interacting with the public and working with kids isn't your thing, then this probably isn't the job for you.

job_title: Research Laboratory Specialist Lead in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Excellent access to research resources. Friendly people at all levels. Good medical options. Reasonable pay. Quiet work environment for senior personnel. Very good paid time off and sick leave options.
cons: Poor advancement options and opportunities for research staff. Uneven and unfair pay scales for staff scientists. Research staff salaries and positions are too dependent on vagaries of grants and size of grants, rather than experience and capability.

job_title: Food Service Worker in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Everyone is hired, and the job is super easy. The managers are very lenient and as along as you do your job right, they will not be difficult on you. Your experience may vary depending on which dorm you work in; North Quad is by far the cleanest and best run, and West Quad is the scum of the earth in every aspect.
cons: Working such a menial job can get boring after a few months. If you are working in the dishroom or washing pots and pans, you do not get to see new people and likely will get bored out of your mind very quickly.

review_title: Teaching in the school of Letters, Sciences and Arts (LSA)
job_title: Lecturer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Lecturers have an opportunity to get $500 annually to spend on presenting papers in conferences.
They pay for books and other teaching materials you need for your classes.
Health insurance and a basic dental insurance for lecturers who teach at least 2 courses per semester.
cons:
No raises or bonuses are offered to Lecturers within the department.
They won't even give you raise even if you make the case and ask.
Lecturers get annual contracts, so there is no job security from one year to the other, and from one semester to the next semester.
Employees have to pay to park on campus, and it's expensive for someone who makes borderline poverty level salary.

job_title: Anonymous in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Great places to work
Benefits are second to none.
Won't ever be shut down
Stable Employer
Great work/life balance
Dependent on job but many opportunities to move else where
cons:
Stuck up doctors/nurses
Pay is lower than private industry
Change is very slow
Raises are usually standard 2% (even if better merit than others)
Management vary in quality
Some employees have made entry level or mid management their life time positions, therefore you get stuck working with them on occassion.

review_title: A dynamic and diverse environment to be in as a student and an array of organizations one is able to get involved with.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Easy to get involved in anything you may have an interest in. Campus is a college town and the perfect size. Every student here is striving to be the best they can be so it's a competitive atmosphere, but that only inspired those who don't mind some competition.
cons: Technical and quantitative skills are not particularly taught or emphasized within liberal arts majors. Computer programs like R, Stata, or even Microsoft Excel are not utilized in these classes and prove to be a deficiency upon graduation and application to any sort of job.

review_title: great place to be a postdoc
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Outstanding benefits, good work-life balance, Ann Arbor is a great location with tons of things to do. Very high quality academic atmosphere at the university. Academic resources are world class.
cons: Housing and groceries in ann arbor are expensive compared to the rest of the region, and a lot of job attributes are idiosyncratic to supervisor (no different than any other institution). Winters are brutal and MI is not the most politically or economically greatest place to be in the country.

review_title: My stent at U of M was chaotic and stressful.
job_title: Meeting and Events Coordinator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Tuition reimbursement and retirement match. The company overall Seems to farm their new employees in pretty quickly!
cons: The Integrative Systems and Design through the college of Engineering lied in an unemployment hearing stating they did not mention Michigan at Will when they fired me only after 3 1/2 days because I asked for a modification to their ridiculous training schedule. Two of four people in the team interview were either resigning or on a medical leave for stress. No one who knew what to do to train a brand new person was made available, no training manual, no set processes for on boarding a brand new employee. I have never hated some where in my entire life and left a company of 26 years to take this position

review_title: Very laid-back place to work, great people
job_title: Data Programmer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The city, environment and the laid-back style of running the company. The managers don't really care what you do as long as you get your job done. The manager-employer relationship is based very heavily on the honor system. Lots of resources available, and obviously the university is _right_ there, which is amazing given all the cool people that you see. Ann Arbor is an amazing place to live,
cons: The kids at school can ruin the weekends for you, lots of drunk 18 year olds, but if you're into that, then it's cool.

review_title: So many amazing people, ideas, but so much red tape.
job_title: Marketing Communications Specialist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Truly some wonderful people who value the mission of a public university and the promise that quality public education and leading research can offer.  There are a lot of resources available to employees and a very generous benefits system.  Also, while the pay does not match peer private institutions, it does run better than many other public universities in the US.
cons: The decentralized nature of the U-M leads to the expected silos and turf battles that extend well beyond academics and into all levels of the life of the university.

job_title: Student Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Michigan Dining part-time has been a popular destination for students who look to be employed on campus. It offers flexible hours and decent pay for a first, or convenient, job that doesn't require too much thinking. There are higher ranks to move into, too! There are different departments, too; outside of dining halls there are cafes and markets.
cons: It can be a little taxing since our customers are college-age kids, like well, one of us. Just imagine what you normally would do in a dining hall, and that's what you have to deal with as a Michigan Dining employee.

job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I love being able to work among the best and the brightest here at the U of M. Rubbing shoulders with well-known researchers and authors is fun, and great networking. I feel like I have freedom to work how and when I want, especially since I'm part time.
cons:
Being "Intermittent", I'm never sure how many (if any) classes I will get to teach each semester, so it's hard to plan my life around. You only get benefits if you have so many classes, so I'd prefer having a more set schedule each semester.
Also.. pay is really not that great at all. They say that the Union has made great gains in this area, but it's still sadly really low!

job_title: Program Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: One of the best (and only) internationally respected employers left in the state of Michigan. It is an environment in which most people are very happy to research, teach, and learn.
cons: Work (as well as academic) quality varies considerably depending on specific department and college. Some departments are excellent while others routinely overwork and/or underpay. There seriously needs to be more job opportunities for Masters students.

review_title: UM is a top tier research university that really takes care of its employees.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: UM has excellent health and fringe benefits for all its employees (postdocs, research staff, and staff alike).  The people there are smart and the environment is generally stimulating, especially with all the seminars available. Ann Arbor is also a nice college town with a lot of culture, for its Midwestern location.  The entrepreneurial vision the school is trying to pass on to it's students is also quite progressive.
cons: Unfortunately, there isn't a very good local industry network to tap into and the good things stop at the university, with little options beyond it.  That's out of UM's control though.

job_title: Associate Director in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Good benefits, opportunities to move within the company, may offer work flexibility. Satisfied with maternity leave. For employees who've been there over a year, they have paid leave starting 2 weeks before due date and 6-8 weeks after birth. You can take off up to a year and they will try to hold your position. You also get the week off between Christmas and New Years.
cons: Your job can change in a moment due to leadership changes or priority changes. Depending on how big your department is, it maybe difficult to get to know other staff.

review_title: Excellent organization depending on the department you work in.
job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I love the benefits package, especially the retirement match. Excellent healthcare and vision/dental benefits as well. HR is very responsive to requests and very helpful.
cons: The parking situation is horrendous on the medical campus. You have to pay for parking that you may or may not be able to use on any given day. Anything but the best parking passes require a mild hike which is fine in the warmer months but not so in the colder months.

job_title: Graduate Student (Instructor, Research, Administrator, Organizer) in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great benefits for Graduate Students thanks to our Graduate Employment Organization (GEO). Great benefits for student parents (subsidized daycare costs). Great place to grow intellectually
cons: Because it is very decentralized, different departments offer different pay for graduate students which can sometimes be insulting. The Rackham Graduate School and the Library has tried to match the hourly rate of the GEO contract and that has been wonderful.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Interesting people, central campus is beautiful, university has a lot of power, excellent benefits for faculty and staff
cons: Like any university, U of M takes advantage of the fact that it is perceived as benevolent and caring toward students. Some faculty and staff are because they are, by nature, good people, but overall faculty and staff are not under pressure to act in students' best interest, and it can be demoralizing to watch callous faculty. Also, like any large organization, HR is mainly under pressure to represent the interests of the organization and not those of its employees. They may take care of employee needs very well, but that is not primarily what they are hired for.

review_title: Excellent benefits, interesting work, slow advancement
job_title: Software Engineer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
- Running things at scale.
- Being the first to work with new technologies.
- Fantastic healthcare and retirement.
cons:
- Dicey funding for some projects.
- Developing stuff and maintaining it isn't a focus for many projects, just a requirement of the grant.
- It's challenging to move up with the same speed as industry positions.
- Technical staff are occasionally ignored compared to those who want to become professional meeting attenders.

job_title: Immigration in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I have a fabulous supervisor, great flexibility and more vacation days than most private sector jobs. It's a relatively low stress position with fair pay and a good work space.
cons: The upper level leadership was difficult to work with and lacked experience and knowledge in the field. The leadership created an in-office PC culture, which was reflective of the broader Student Life culture, and her presence had a chilling effect in the office. Morale was incredibly low during her tenure. However, this is changing with new leadership. Other cons--the work is repetitive and the office needs improvements (i.e. ceiling tiles are damaged, lights, temperature control, etc.). There is little room for upward mobility or growth.
