review_title: A great place to work if you're more concerned about quality of life than about salary
job_title: Staff Specialist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Benefits are excellent, lots of vacation, and you work with (and often for) really smart people.  And you know your company isn't going to be sold or shut down.  It's a stable employer.  Also, in most parts of the University, there isn't a lot of pressure.  (This varies.)
cons: Pay is lower than in private industry (but see benefits above), and raises are terrible.  Not as exciting.  Few opportunities for travel in most positions.  Quality of management varies dramatically.  Some very dysfunctional people can get entrenched, and you have to work with them.

job_title: Program Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The work environment is generally hospitable and open. Working for the university allows for academic and career networking. The university seems to have an array of job postings uploaded on a daily basis to its employment website. Because of this, students can find job openings related to their given area of study and/or research.
cons: Hard to move up in departments, given the abundance of qualified and over-qualified candidates within Ann Arbor. Work can sometimes spill over outside of your office hours, especially through email. It can be difficult to obtain an on-campus job as a non-work study student. Some of the work-study jobs pay on the lower-end of the pay rate scale.

job_title: IT Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Excellent benefits, especially retirement; plenty of vacation and sick time, so very helpful for people with children. Highly accomplished community of people from students to staff to faculty. Facilities vary depending on where you work, but can be very good. Generally caring, decent management and coworkers.
cons: Immense size means the staff experience can vary greatly from person to person. That means everything from management to environment. In some units people can become complacent making it hard to get things done.

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: There are incredible opportunities for research at UofM, and potentially a chance to truly distinguish yourself at a globally well-reputed institution.
cons: As in all academia, pay is low and continued employment mostly uncertain (before tenure). Opportunities at UofM depend very heavily upon the leadership of the research-group.

review_title: Part-time student employee at University of Michigan Housing (Computer Consultant)
job_title: Computer Consultant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The office culture was student oriented, which is helpful if you are a part-time employee, and the office benefits (free coffee and now even a few meals) is well above average for part-time jobs in Ann Arbor. The pay was average given the skillset necessary for my position. Generally flexible schedules.
cons: There is not much room for career growth seeing as it is a part-time job. In addition, some of the tasks seemed menial and below my skill level. However, this was made clear to me during my interview.

review_title: I worked in the IT Department and was basically in charge of helping the students as well as the staff with problems.
job_title: Tech Desk Operative in Detroit, MI
pros: Benefits include being able to work on school work, personal time, social time. Work is not really that difficult after a while of doing it, which can be a pro or a con.
cons: Basically the same work again and again. Gets boring after a few months. The benefits are basically none besides a work-study grant. Opportunity for a raise are very sleek.

job_title: Audio Visual Technician in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great coworkers and support systems- hands down the best place to work in Ann Arbor (probably in Michigan, too).  Excellent benefits, opportunities to get yourself trained in fields of interest, and really respectful managing/scheduling.
cons: Not a ton of opportunities to "advance" or get a higher position.  But that's part of the nature of this field of work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
- good health coverage and vacation
- interesting and smart people to work with - its one of the best public universities!
cons: - for being a university, there is a stark contrast between the age of students and then the age of the administration. Being a Millenial one of my biggest frustrations has been working with majority older workers (near or past retirement age) who may not have updated their skills in decades.

job_title: Senior Human Resources Representative in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Environment champions health and well being and provides excellent programs to support fitness and working out.  Policies tend to be employee oriented.  My experience has been very favorable to good work/life balance, although I don't think that holds true across the board. My co-workers and manager are a very respectful and genuinely nice group of people who bring good skills to the job and are willing to share information.
cons: Consensus driven decision making, which slows down the decision making process.  Decentralized structure is not very efficient for an organization of this size.

review_title: Research Assistant / Intern at Walter E. Lay Automotive Lab
job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great work atmosphere | Thousands of research opportunities | Fully funded PhD. | Helpful staff | Great university campus | Opportunity to learn a lot
cons: Ann arbor is an expensive town | Delayed payment, I was supposed to get paid bi weekly, but half of the time there was monthly payment. Interns may just float if they do not a specific project to work upon.

review_title: Great University, Incredibly Stingy with Salary
job_title: Research Lab Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Wonderful location, good benefits once you're full-time. I know time off depends on which department you are employed for, but I was promised 12 vacation days/year
cons: I have a Bachelor's degree and my offered salary was 30K. I could do the same thing (manage a lab) at another university for way more money and that's taking cost of living into consideration as well. Custodial staff is general paid 30K

review_title: My job at U of M has been an excellent experience, I am treated with respect and am part of a collaborative team
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: flexible hours, collaboration, learning environment, fair pay, friendly coworkers, great work ethic, respect, social and community involvement, best practices, access to excellent databases, technology and software
cons: lunch breaks are unpaid, no windows in office, some workers seem unqualified for their position, dark office, working at a cubicle, sometimes difficult to work under university's requirements and regulations

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Michigan is a great public research university, with lots of strong programs. Ann Arbor is a great town. If you get a postdoctoral offer here that looks good, it probably is good.
cons: Some programs aren't great, some people don't like living in a smallish Midwestern town, even a cosmopolitan university town. University-wide postdoc support is so-so, but that's probably true everywhere. Salaries are lower than at a national lab. Cost of living is cheap compared to a big city, but expensive compared to most towns this size.

review_title: For a summer job, I was very satisfied.
job_title: Labor Mechanic I in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: North Campus Housing facilities is very laid back, depending on the crew.  They allowed for time off with not very much notice, and they were very friendly.
cons: If you are a temporary worker, it is very difficult to become a full time employee at the University.  It feels like you need to know someone in order to get your foot in the door.

review_title: Lots of work for little pay, but you get a degree at the end...
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Medium to good academic reputation. Many advisors allow flexible hours.  Good overall level of support from other graduate students.  Good opportunities for activities outside work/classes.
cons: Low pay compared with similar educational level in industry.  Sometimes long hours are needed to get things done.  Quality of advisors as managers is hit-or-miss.  Oppressive union policies by graduate student union.

review_title: Mostly positive, but sometimes it is difficult to find who to go to for answers to questions
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I think that the University of Michigan has some of the best benefits in health care and retirement. People here are also very collaborative and willing to help.
cons: It is difficult to find out who has the information you need to get questions answered. For example, when my boss wanted to change my job title and give me a raise, it was difficult to find out what our options were based on my education level, experience and expectations.

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Strong union and therefore great health care benefits
U of M has countless networking and professional development opportunities but you have to be your own advocate
cons:
The wages are too low for Ann Arbor
Work experience will vary according to the professor you are working with. Some value your input on how the class is run and taught, others don't. Some respect your time, others don't. 
There can be professor-grad student conflicts, and in my experience, the grad student always loses. 
Efforts made to professionalize graduate students very greatly between departments

job_title: Information Resources Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Full time employees get great benefits and compensation.  Good people work there, living in Ann Arbor is a great experience, the city is absolutely amazing!  They hire entry level well paying positions.  It's also great work for students, very laid back.  Sometimes you get to move around to different university buildings and walking around at U of M can be a joy!
cons: Difficult to park around campus if you don't have staff parking.  Parking in garages can add up.  They are very strict against sending personal emails and messages on work computers and office jobs can be very boring, especially when working alone.

review_title: Steer clear.  The national repuation for arrogance and pretentiousness is accuarate.  Very unwelcoming for women.
job_title: Director in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The education deleivered to students is amoung the best in the state.  The town of Ann Arbor has lovely trees.
cons: The envirornment is not friendly to women, sad given that the president and highest ranking leader at the health system are female.  A friend recently filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.  The government investigator's response, when learning it was against the University was: "Again, the University of Michigan? There is only one other organization in this four state field office service area with more complaints."

job_title: Research Administrator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Internal promotions/ they tend to take care of their own.  Some departments offer flexible work schedules to accommodate for child care, illness, bad weather, etc.
cons: Some people who have been in their jobs for years become very lazy and make way more money than those who should make it.  On the flip side, I know some people who have been in their positions for years and deserve a huge raise but when you are funded by research dollars and that PI doesn't bring in money, you don't get the raises.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The hours are very flexible. Taking time off is always allowed. You also have a lot of vacation days, sick days and personal days to use. It was a positive and welcoming environment. Coffee, hot chocolate, tea and water were always in the kitchen. The work was pretty easy once I caught on to it. I enjoyed my time at UofM.
cons: Sometimes there is not much to do. I would end of sitting at my desk reviewing projects I already reviewed. There needs to be ore structure to the jobs and positions. It would also be nice if the upper management would let you know how you were doing.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Amazing colleagues and fantastic experience teaching students who were, for the most part, very engaged. Supportive atmosphere. Opportunity to innovate with syllabi, course design, and assessments given to students.
cons: Low pay and lack of job stability. The union helps with things like ensuring benefits, but until you've been there three years and undergone a review, you won't be guaranteed teaching from one semester to the next.

job_title: PhD Candidate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: University of Michigan was a great experience in terms of both the size of the student body and the amount of resources available to the students. The faculty in the Aerospace  Engineering department came from a variety of backgrounds and expertise which made a very strong and diverse department.
cons: Some of the coursework could have been more streamlined in the sense that while the university aims to offer a well rounded education, some of the required coursework seemed somewhat restrictive in the sense that there were sometimes too many credit requirements and as such it felt like you had less choice on your direction of study.

review_title: A plethora of organizational cultures, across the spectrum of horrible to great.
job_title: Marketing Communications Specialist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: If you stay connected to the mission, it can be inspiring, and the benefits are great.
cons: Death by bureaucracy, for one thing.  And on the individual unit level, you are just too far removed from where big decisions are made - it can often feel like you are just a cog in the wheel.

review_title: Pleasant working environment with lots of opportunities for networking and future career development
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Job security, great benefits, and less of a corporate mentality: generally speaking, workers aren't treated simply as an easily disposable cog
cons: Hours worked very on a daily to weekly basis, but expect to bring your work home, often (depending on what you end up doing). More then likely will have summers off, depending on what you do. Not as many perks as a corporation, but generally a really good package. Lower salary but a more distinguished position. If you stick around long enough, you will be well taken care of, or at least taken care of.

review_title: Great institution, very proud to represent!
job_title: Development Services
pros: I had the hands down, most incredible team and managers/directors.  Always encouraged to broaden my horizons and learn as much as I wanted.  Also made me genuinely passionate about my work everyday in the Office of University Development (OUD).  I would have never left if circumstances allowed.
cons: Many will say salary, that will generally go without saying in the world of nonprofit work though and you should be well aware you're in this industry because the work you do is priceless.  A lower salary doesn't hinder me from being able to be part of such a great organization.

review_title: The College of Engineering is a great place to work
job_title: Marketing Communications Specialist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The majority of faculty and staff show respect and appreciation to one another. The campus is beautiful and there are many affordable transportation options to get there. Entry level salaries are competitive.
cons: The University never closes due to poor weather, causing a loss of vacation time for most. Some faculty and students will make unreasonable requests, but generally staff supervisors will help when this happens. Due to the great job security, some lackluster employees stick around much longer than they should, and that can be a burden.

review_title: Great benefits, poor management mediocre pay
job_title: Client/Server Programmer Senior in Canton, MI
pros: I get lots of vacation time plus pretty good health benefits for relatively low cost. The support for my family, even if it's not officially a family is good.
cons: Being in IT, many of the managers have been pulled also from IT, but not really given adequate training. Additionally the current CIO is intent on turning this into a corporate IT shop.

review_title: Great school for biological science PhD
job_title: Graduate Student in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great school with lots of science funding and plenty of intellectual stimulation. The quality of mentorship in the Cell & Developmental Biology program has been great and I am enabled to do impactful, basic biological science research. There is also a great environment of collaboration and sharing amongst the labs within my department
cons: The area is northern Michigan, so the winter is always rough (although manageable). There is no parking on campus, but the university and public transit systems are fairly good.

review_title: A clean professional environment perfectly suited to scientific research.
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: It's a top tier research University, so it has a lot of resources available.  Also, faculty, students, and postdocs are very professional.  Also, people are very courteous in Michigan!
cons: As you get used to working at a top tier research University, you come to realize that a lot of people are full of themselves.  It can become quite annoying!

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Classes and professors are top notch, professors care about student's development and knowledge base. It also affords great benefits (seminars, speakers, etc.) to a student looking to broaden their knowledge and understanding. Allows for great opportunities afterwords.
cons: Like any graduate student, the pay is not much for the long hours required. Additionally, the office conditions are not ideal, as many graduate students are stuck in a small office with multiple people.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
- Fantastic health insurance. Best I've seen for graduate students.
- Great stipend. Visiting professors *jokingly* ask us not to tel their students how much we make.
- They clearly care about their students and employees and make an effort to take care of them.
cons: - No complaints that relate to the company as a whole. Anyone considering coming here should closely investigate the department they'll be joining, as the work environment varies wildly between departments.

job_title: Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Health coverage is comprehensive and reasonable; retirement investment options and contribution are good; holiday, vacation and sick leave are fantastic; free bus pass is outstanding if you can afford to live in the A2 area.
cons: Although there is attention to wellness, gym memberships are still pricey and not all that convenient for most of campus.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
1) There are a lot of resources on campus that are openly available to all UMICH members.
2) The strong reputation of UMICH will take you far.
cons: The biggest disadvantage would have to be the lack of clarity where to find these helpful resources. If I don't know where it is, it might as well not exist. Lack of web search engines to help you find appropriate resources.

review_title: Great benefits, secure job, liberal environment
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Secure job. Takes a lot to get fired (as witnessed - a coworker who abused their powers), which sort of rides the fence of entitlement. Nonetheless, secure. Great place to settle in, ride it out, do the bare minimum, and retire with a cushy plan. Hey, it's government money, right?
cons: Diversity and acceptance is widely touted (until you disagree with their political or moral viewpoints). Under average page in general - university wide - unless you're "upper brass."

job_title: Senior Supervisor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great benefits! 403B and vacation time was second to none. Name recognition was also a plus. If you can deal with the headaches and B.S. keep in mind It will not look bad on your resume if you worked for the U of M when looking to move on
cons: Upper management was very closed minded and micromanaged EVERYTHING! The organization would preach change management but were not open to new ideas. For what was expected the pay was WAY below scale but the additional benefits (403B and vacation) helped make it worthwhile. The trades, AFSCME and IUOE unions represented every bad thing unions stand for. They were too busy trying to make sure that others were not doing “their work” that the actual work never got done. The "management team” was no better. . . There must be a rule that management and hourly employees can get along because both groups seemed to be looking for things to argue about as opposed to seeking compromises. I have never worked for a place with so many disgruntled employees at all levels. That said, if you can go to work everyday and not want to make a difference, accept the status quo, love a bureaucratic workplace with trust issues this might be the place for you.

review_title: Make sure you weigh the pros and cons before working here.
job_title: Administrative/Project Coordinator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great benefits package with choices for customization, including medical, dental, and vision. Plus plenty of sick and vacation time. Some of the senior level management team is interested in mentoring those beneath them. You don't feel pressured to stay late or work weekends, unless you want to. Flexible schedules, for the most part. Fairly easy to move around the different areas of the University, making it easy to try new things. Extensive offers for professional training, with GREAT instructors.
cons: Some departments are a little less focused on the "team environment" and more on personal gain. Many of the top-level managers don't care about lower level employees, and with take mid-level managers word on performance measures, without finding out for themselves. Many of the mid-level managers in my particular area feel threatened right now because of a "climate" change in our department, so myself and a few of my peers have been "thrown under the bus" in our evaluations. There is a very slow growth pattern here, often requiring employees to move around the university in order to move vertically - which isn't usually a significant step up. The salary levels here are quite a bit lower than the market average, since it is a non-profit institution. There is also a large disparity in salary levels between management and those under them (i.e. you either make the average, or you make well above average). Many of the internal departments are unorganized and often don't complete projects unless you are constantly bugging them, making your job very difficult at times.

review_title: I loved the stimulating research environment at the U of M Med School
job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Awesome reputation and high-quality programs provide for the best professional stimulation for young academics. Great benefits and fabulous resources add to the great experience.
cons: There is a competitive culture (though that's not necessarily a con), which can lead to stressful times. But then again, that is something we all experience pretty much anywhere. The winters in Michigan can be pretty harsh too ;-)

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Amazing Health care package as a GSI, better than faculty and staff. Intelligent and eager student body to work with.  GEO, graduate student union is amazing at helping to keep your job safe and within the guidelines of what is stated in the contract, so that you can keep up with your own studies in addition to teaching.
cons: Hours can go over - but GEO is good at helping resolve issues around going over your allotted hours.  Art department GSI positions are some of the lowest on Campus. Overall it is a great position though and helps keep your tuition down!

review_title: An excellent place to work and study
job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I studied here as an undergraduate and graduate student, working for the university while in graduate school. My overall experience was outstanding. The environment is collegial and professional, and the quality of academics is among the best in the country. Graduate student workers and lecturers are unionized, so salaries for these positions are very competitive.
cons: Unfortunately, because regular university staff are not unionized, the salary for a professional staff member might be lower than that of a graduate student assistant.

review_title: Great benefits, Horrible politics (at least in my department)
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great benefits, super intelligent students, staff and colleagues and cutting edge program development.
cons:
Large institution political bull crap
The same senior level people stay in their position for a long time and while they hire people claiming they want to bring innovation and help address issues with their team, they are quick to get you in line once you are on their staff.

job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
*  As a member of the faculty or staff community on our campuses or in our Health System, you will be a part of the Michigan Difference – working in an organization that is dedicated to improving lives through research, learning and service.

    * You will have opportunity to grow personally and professionally in a challenging and stimulating environment that encourages individual development.

    * You will be part of an organization with abundant artistic, cultural, social and educational opportunities.
cons: The weather is very cold over here

job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great place to work that gives you autonomy to complete tasks.  Management is excellent, very smart and approachable.  The team is hard working and happy to help out wherever possible.  Also, insurance benefits are a great plus.
cons: When business is slow it can be hard to know what to do.  This creates wasted down time.  Other than that there are not many cons to working to working here.

job_title: Biomedical Engineer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: At the university, there are top researchers and experts in a variety of fields.  Particularly in biomedical engineering, there are a variety of resources to have meaningful research or resources for development.
cons: Sometimes, classes are big and it's easy to get lost.  However, there are resources to help develop your own voice, and staff and professors are incredibly receptive to meeting new people.

review_title: Great benefits, amazing location, not ideal if you're looking for flexibility
job_title: Marketing Communications Specialist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: One of the most obvious perks of working at the U is the feeling that you're moving the world forward. You get to feel as though your work is part of something bigger, and that you're having a positive impact on your community and on the future. Also, you get to work in one of the coolest cities in the midwest - there is never a shortage of things to do or after-work happy hours to attend. Great benefits, healthcare, retirement plan, etc. Amazing vacation/sick time, even as a new employee. Lots of cool people around too.
cons:
Varies from department to department, so my review might not be accurate to other schools/colleges/units. In my personal experience, there is very little flexibility in terms of when/where you work. I have a medical condition that makes it hard for me to work an 8-5 schedule consistently but I'm unable to work from home, so I've ended up burning through a lot of my sick time when it would have been better for all parties involved if I could just adjust my schedule or telecommute occasionally. If working remotely isn't your thing anyway, this will be an incredible job for you. 

One other small con is that, depending on the S/C/U, you are working in academia, so there is a bit of baggage that comes along with that. Sometimes it's a great thing, but sometimes it means that people get so caught up in semantics or "doing things the way we've always done them" that they don't end up getting anything done at all. This isn't a good job for people who like to work on their own or be self-guided.

As a recent grad, the pay is just enough to get by but definitely not anything great. Again, this will vary by department.

job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Generous vacation and retirement benefits.  Work is likely to be flexible.  Wide variety of work is available on campus.  Lots of interesting things are going on.  Access to excellent libraries.  Free bus pass.  Many opportunities to learn new skills, if you look for them.
cons: It is a large institution.  Conditions may vary depending on who you work with.  Departments and individual research groups vary.   On grant funding, job stability varies.

review_title: Should have never in the first place but glad to be back
job_title: Senior Web Administrator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Very flexible when it comes to family life.
Excellent benefits and ways to increase your skills and knowledge.
Working in Ann Arbor is a treat and being surrounded by nice place to grab lunch is a perk.
cons: Things can get pretty comfortable working at UM and you may lose touch of emerging technologies.

review_title: I enjoyed my time as an employee at the University of Michigan and would return if my career heads back that direction.
job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I had a flexible work schedule that allowed me to go in and out of the office as I pleased as long as my work was done in a timely manner.
cons: Sometimes I felt like I was stuck in neutral while I was there.  The opportunities to advance quickly didn't seem like they were there.

job_title: Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: One of the top research universities in the world, providing phenomenal resources and opportunities in nearly every discipline.  Being in biomedical engineering, I have the best of two great research areas within the school:  engineering and medicine, both are top-rated programs.  Its medical complex is one of the largest, most comprehensive college-owned centers of its kind in the world.
cons: It can be very overwhelming at times.  I got my Ph.D. here, but I would not attend this institution as an undergraduate as I would feel more like a number instead of as a person.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: U of M offers employees excellent benefits and fair pay. There are a fair number of opportunities to move around within the university. Ann Arbor is a very nice place to live, and the university campus is very well kept up.
cons: Perhaps as expected with any government associated workplace, there are some tedious protocols in place that one must frequently deal with. However, my experience has been that coworkers are willing to assist when the red tape is especially convoluted.

review_title: Possibly the best place to work in Michigan
job_title: Project Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The people, location, and benefits are hard to beat.
cons: The nature of many of the salaried jobs can push some of us to work well beyond a 40 hour work week.  Departments are trying to improve work/life balance but there's still some work to be done.

review_title: Great Benefits, Management Not So Much
job_title: Web Designer Developer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: UofM offers great benefits including PTO, health & dental insurance; name recognition;
cons: Campus doesn't have free parking. Monthly paid parking pass gives you right to "hunt" for parking space - no guarantees. Even if you find a space, then must walk long distances to office. Lower than average industry pay rates. In my department: nepotism, favoritism, unqualified management with raging temper. Outdated buildings with asbestos;  HR exists to protect upper management.

review_title: Great place to work as a student
job_title: Sites Consultant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: It is great to be able to work as a student at the Campus Computing SItes as the workload is never overwhelming, you get to work as much or as little as you want, and you make great friends with both the other staffers and the management.  Highly recommended.
cons: It may not be relevant work experience that will get you a professional job after graduation, if that's what you are looking for.

review_title: Interested in a staff position? Proceed with caution, especially transplants.
job_title: Senior Media Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
- Great insurance benefits, including 14 days of upfront sick leave annually. Vision coverage was the best I've had.
- Fun staff appreciation events
- Central campus is in the heart of downtown Ann Arbor
- Having UMich on your resume will help you stand out to future employers
- It's often notoriously difficult for external candidates with no prior UMich affliation to get in, so if you are one and you do, it increases your chances of moving up into a different/better position.
- Full time, permanent positions are very stable (assuming you pass the probationary period)
- You will have the opportunity to interact with lots of brilliant people.
cons:
- Staff pay is terribly inadequate against the rapidly increasing cost of living for Ann Arbor. I started out making $14/hr, and more than 2 years later, I was only making $14.48. I couldn't find a crappy studio apartment for under $1100/month. We had no Union and no one to help us advocate for better pay.
- Not transplant-friendly. I absolutely do not recommend moving here as an outsider without prior social connections. It can easily take at least 1-3 years to form a social life.
- A lot of faculty and students are highly impatient, rude, and think they are the smartest / most important people around. They will expect you to immediately cater to every whim, whether they understand your department policies or not. I have worked for multiple universities...but the disrespect I witnessed on a daily basis was astounding and unrivalled. Part of it probably has to do with many people coming from highly privileged backgrounds (particularly being very wealthy and/or never having needed to work an hourly position outside of academia).

review_title: Looking for a job based on research
job_title: Research Assistant in Detroit, MI
pros: I had opportunity to work with several other universities but I choose this university because they were paying me good amount of money
cons: When initially yous start the work as a research assistant you need to spend more and more time and then you get use to it but sometimes it may happen that when you are not getting result you need to quit because of frustration

job_title: Program Coordinator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: University of Michigan is prestigious and proud, working here, this rubs off on you. There's lots of building renovations happening and chances are your office is fancy and new. The U works hard to cultivate a community with lots of events and you're a part of it. There's a tuition reimbursement program (not 100%) if you're interested in taking UM classes.
cons: Despite the prestige of UM, most of the time it felt like a boring desk job, They're so well functioning, there's not much work and lots of waiting for someone to give me a task/project to work on.

review_title: World-class research in an extremely supportive environment... but, 40h/ weeks, not happening.
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: You will find an incredibly supportive environment, with world-class researchers that value collaboration, professional and personal growth. There is something magical about the midwest culture that promotes growth rather than prevent it.
cons: Work-life balance is up to you, and it is *expected* that you work beyond the typical 40h/ week. For me this is a non-issue, as I love what I do, but on the difficult days... it would be nice to stick to a 9am-5pm schedule with benefits and a salary that my contemporaries enjoy in industry.

job_title: Community Center Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: U-M housing is full of good people. The CCAs and RAs are 90% great to chat with and are always willing to lend a hand during their shifts.
cons: Upper management did not respect us as people or students. They implemented rules and tasks outside of our original contract. The contract itself is ridiculous - we were not allowed to speak out publicly against Housing. It felt like a cult at times where we needed to pretend to be super happy.

review_title: Good, solid place to work with some caveats
job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Excellent benefits, holiday time, and vacation immediately upon hiring in. Friendly, extremely casual work atmosphere (in IT anyway!) with lots of knowledgeable, talented staff. What you know is clearly more important than how you look or dress! Flexibility in scheduling and a great work/life balance. Our manager, at least, meets with us on a regular basis for casual status sessions so we always have feedback on performance and what's coming in the future. It's kind of a comfortable "free to be" place to work where toes don't get stepped on very often and diversity and acceptance are very much in evidence. Opportunities to take advantage of University resources such as lectures and seminars you normally wouldn't hear about.
cons: The pay I receive is 60% of what I would make doing the same thing in industry or manufacturing. Job classifications and corresponding pay rate brackets are seemingly inflexible and moving up in salary without getting major, infrequently offered promotions looks impossible. There is a trend toward hiring end-dated employees with full benefits but a job end date (not a contract ). They often renew end-dated employees, but lately they do it less, and they tend to string you along the last couple months not knowing if you're extended or not. The work is generally not complicated and cycles from being too busy to not busy enough. It's easy to get bored. It's a very insular place to be and many people have never worked anywhere else and never plan to leave until they retire. It means a lot of people are entrenched, don't like change, don't have a business perspective outside University operations, are used to living on the fat of the Michigan taxpayers and speak in an acronym-laden language that makes it extremely difficult for outsiders to come in and hit the ground running. There is a lot of "opting in" to offered systems and tools rather than standardizing on one (such as email, document management, time reporting, etc) A lot of money is wasted because departments in large part get to do what they want; it's impossible for the U to achieve any economies of scale or standard, cross-departmental processes/functions because it's so politically correct and "nice", the words "no" and "thou shalt" are heard much less often than they should be!

job_title: GSRA in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The compensation package for GSRAs in engineering pays well and has great health benefits. Many companies recruit at UM and not smaller schools because they know UM has top notch students. This give you many opportunities for future employment. Ann Arbor is a great place to live.
cons: Long hours are required to balance the work load from classes and PhD research. Expectations are high. The weather during the school year can be depressing, but if you spend all your time in the lab then you don't notice the 35* rain.

review_title: Would recommend to busy students looking for part-time work
job_title: Document Scanner, Taubman Medical Library in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Flexible schedule, friendly/helpful supervisors, work relatively straightforward
cons: No real possibility for advancement, though that's to be expected--MLibrary is aware that this might dissatisfy some employees and thus has modest wage increases tied to number of hours logged--UM Housing is much better is this regard, odd aberrations in the library's organization (the alphabetization system, for instance, occasionally counts punctuation as letters, causing journals to not be where they should be), ILLiad scanner client prone to crashes, lack of other libraries informal benefits (e.g. more convenient location, more interaction among staff, snacks, etc.)

review_title: A Day of Teaching and Being Taught
job_title: Math Tutor in Dearborn, MI
pros: It is a cultural experience.  The diversity is complex and rich and rustiness is not known.  It is a well oiled machine.  Lives are lived here, generations of students define themselves in their transition.  Much is learned, even as more is mentioned in passing.
cons: They keep their god close though, for a public university.  The pay is terrible.  More important though, math needs to be taught on an individual level.  Classroom settings numb students that could otherwise develop in math.

review_title: Great place to work especially during school
job_title: Student Worker in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: A Great place to work especially during school. The people throughout are amazing, great to work with and great to talk with. A very relaxed environment for a student and can get some studying done often. Left alone mostly as long as you get your work done. Great pay for the work and incredibly helpful for side money while in school.
cons: A lot of physical labor and often monotonous. Not good work for when you're not having a good day but motivates you to study.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Excellent benefits, caring environment in many departments
cons: Interests of the school are not particularly well aligned with those of students (undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral), as is the case at all research universities. Recent overemphasis (also the case at most  universities) on translational/practical research instead of high-risk basic research. In humanities departments, poor outlook for graduate students and researchers (also the case at nearly all universities).

job_title: Field Interviewer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: In theory, you can pick your own hours.
cons: Low pay; work is not guaranteed; there are no benefits  - not even  break on tuition;  they say you can work up to 40 hours but they only give you work for 20;  no one to ask questions to as when you do, you are told to 'fill out a form"; Work load and directions can change on a moments notice.

review_title: Good Benefits - but watch your hours
job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: University provided good compensation, good health benefits for graduate student instructors. I worked with a good professor which made the experience good - anecdotally, other students didn't have as good of luck with their faculty member they were working for.
cons:
- University pays monthly for the stipend instead of bi-weekly
- No extra pay for extra hours worked - so make sure you keep track of your hours. 
- I felt like an outsider to the department I worked in - they didn't provide adequate space for office hours.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Good benefits, relatively competitive salaries compared with similar institutions, lots of opportunities to learn and pick a job that suits you
cons: Policies, politics, and climate vary across depaRtments and work groups. Some people know how to kmanage, others really don't. Finding your place can be a process. Salaries are low compared to industry, and opportunities for advancement can be limited without a MD or PhD.

review_title: Big college with a close personal feel
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Been here as a researcher for 3 years. Really smart people in the faculty that are always willing to collaborate, which leads to many project opportunities. Even though the campus is large it's not difficult to locate local experts on a variety of topics. Undergraduate research training is also very well organized, so lots of chances for mentorship opportunities.
cons: The town itself is a typical college town with few local attractions and can fell a bit slow from time to time. Other than that really not much to complain about :)

job_title: Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: This is a postdoctoral research position at a research institute of the university. Flexible work time as long as you work for 8 hours a day. Good health insurance. Diverse. Great people.
cons: Low salary. Slow work progress. No 401(k) match for this position. Job security is dependent on funding status, and timing of funding coming in is unpredictable.

review_title: Good place to work as a student
job_title: Language Lab Assistant, German Tutor in Brownstown, MI
pros: In my position, the hours are flexible around my class time and depending on your position you can get homework done if it's a slow day. The coworkers are nice and it's not digging ditches
cons: The pay is low (barely above minimum wage for most student positions) and it's very difficult to get positions unless you have a very tight network because so many students apply. There are also no breaks, including for lunch even during an 8-hour shift, but luckily unlike my old job I can eat from my desk.

review_title: UofM is great, Department not so much
job_title: Post Doc in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
- great health benefits
- good professional development for postdocs at Michigan Medicine
- good research infrastructure
- Ann Arbor is a great place to live, although getting increasingly more expensive
- relatively good public transportation to Detroit and Chicago
cons:
- no retirement benefits for post-docs
- extremely short parental leave
- clinical departments have no career development/ coaching/ mentoring for post-docs
- salaries could be higher and grow more with experience

review_title: Great source of funding for graduate students of all sorts, with good healthcare benefits!
job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Salaries and benefits negotiated by the Graduate Employees Union (GEO) so salaries are reasonable for this position for the amount of work required.  Health benefits are excellent.
cons: Benefits could be more expansive outside of healthcare, especially for those graduate students who have families.  It isn't bad, however.

review_title: Entry Level Job without the entry level feel
job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The University has a great community feel.  It is a leader in many areas and I am continually proud to be associated with this employer!
cons: Working for the athletic department of the University is difficult not due to internal complications but to the obligatory regulations of the NCAA.  This makes even the most simple tasks complicated.

review_title: Working for Business and Finance is a drag
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The pay isn't bad and the dress code is pretty relaxed. If you want a job where you can just keep your head down then this might be a good choice
cons: The Business and Finance unit has worked very hard to divorce itself from the rest of the university and wants to know as little as possible about what goes on at the university. If you like being around smart and excited people doing new and interesting things then avoid business and finance like the plague. Business and Finance staff are located off of campus and away from all of the amenities that are normally available at a university.

job_title: Post Doctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great city to live in and commute to work.  Great University to be associated with which helps with proposals that you are submitting.
cons: The lab that you work in and your advisor have direct impact on your success so make sure you are selective in your decision.  As a post doc, paid time off and vacation/holidays may not be very well defined.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: For my position I believe I receive fair compensation and benefits, a good deal of flexibility, and my colleagues are friendly and collaborative. My area is very supportive of diversity in the workplace. The parental leave is not great for my position but I have a faculty friend who had good parental leave (1 semester off teaching, 1 year added to tenure clock).
cons: I haven't experienced any major cons. Others I know in similar positions have - so it just seems that one's supervisor makes a big difference in one's experience here.

review_title: Working in a lab at UM is great if you're right out of college, dont do it longer
job_title: Research Lab Tech Intermediate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Generally present working environment. Great benefits package. They have nice perks like being able to take classes within your school for free.
cons: Low paying and doesn't seem to scale with education or experience. I have a masters degree but i am paid the same as people fresh out of undergrad. The nature of this job is its meant for somebody right out of undergrad who is considering applying to PhD programs, so there's no room for growth really.

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Working here, you're part of a very large, but proud and productive community. Ann Arbor has so much going on and being part of such a cornerstone educational institution, it's almost impossible to not learn something new and amazing every day.
cons: Good luck parking in Ann Arbor without spending a lot. Keep some quarters in your car, maybe. If this is the worst thing I have to report, things must be going pretty well!

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: A high energy place. Intellectually demanding, but a great party setting as well. Scores high on school spirit. Impressive list of alumni who are generally willing to talk to students.
cons: UMich is large and poses typical issues that one would likely face with bureaucracies of that size. Part-time faculty compensation should be raised if the university wants to attract talent.

job_title: Emerging Technologies Consultant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Access to the facilities and software access outside of work for personal endeavors.
cons:
My co-workers tended to be incompetent (constantly blaming one another if something went wrong instead of resolving the issue together).
There was a huge lack of communication skills on all fronts.
HR absolutely sucks.
After being laid off in December, it took them almost 2 months to take me off payroll.

job_title: Secretary Associate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Excellent Health Care Benefits
Great 403b Retirement Match After 6-months
Investment Office Bonus Available After a Full Year of Service
cons:
CYA Culture
Micromanagement of Simple Tasks
No Trust
Constant Need to Watch Your Back
Toxic Personalities
Little to No Communication

job_title: Computer Technician in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Good team to work with. 
Intelligent and hard-working students and researchers. 
Great resources (library, equipment, support staff). 
Good co-operation makes this a good place to work at.
cons:
No clear direction sometimes, so one has to have initiative and presence of mind to anticipate what lies ahead. 
Sometimes people try to add to the already big list of duties, but that would be be anywhere. Not for people who cannot say no.

job_title: Research Specialist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I really enjoyed the camaraderie with my coworkers.  Everyone was enthusiastic about their work and the common goals led to great collaboration.  In addition, the benefits and PTO were great and will be missed.
cons: The pay is somewhat low compared to the private sector and, as a staff researcher, I had no upward mobility without a PhD.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Seattle, WA
pros: As a Teaching Assistant, I can learn more by teaching. Although I got As on those courses, when I faced the real questions from my students, I realized the differences. It will be a great opportunity to be a teaching assistant if you want to master a course by teaching it.
cons: For a teaching assistant, it really depended on your course and Professor. I hope the schedule could be more flexible.

review_title: Transportation Research Institute Assistant in Research
job_title: Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: It is a very casual setting and a comfortable work environment.  We work on studies that have real world safety applications
cons: Someone there is not much work to do.  That being said, that is not always a bad thing.  Work is never stressful so I guess it could be possible to get bored. Not me.

job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great benefits, vibrant small city with lots to do, and lots of room for career advancement and movement within the organization
cons: Decentralization means that information can be hard to come by and many processes are hard to figure out.  After awhile, you can usually figure out who does what and who to contact to get something done, but it does take awhile.

job_title: Computer Lab Proctor in Dearborn, MI
pros: Nice place to work with students from differences background around the planet. The work environment is nice and friendly coworker.
cons: The pay check won't that great, about minimum wage. However, I could not complain because the job is not complicate and on the campus.

review_title: UM is a world-class academic institution with all of the good things and bad things that go with that status.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Good benefits, competitive pay, flexible hours depending on the position.
cons: UM is very hierarchical and if you don't have a strong advocate in your chain-of-command it can be difficult. There is a lot of research money. Women and minorities are given low-ball salaries and raises, especially if they do not have strong advocates.

review_title: Great research experience for undergraduates, with a decent pay rate, and excellent opportunities for future research.
job_title: Researcher in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
- Decent salary for undergraduates
- Experience working in cutting edge research
- Opportunities to involve yourself in further projects
- Mentorship programmes that involve themselves in your success.
cons:
- Some uninterested professors will not provide an absolutely stimulating or particularly educational experience
- Work sometimes is just delegated grunt work for the sake of projects, although this can be a pro of sorts in regards to experience.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The benefits achieved by the Graduate Student Union here are great. Teaching conditions vary greatly because it depends on your supervisor. When you get a good professor, they give you a lot of a freedom to construct your lessons and guidance when you need help.
cons: Again depends on the supervisor. Sometimes they can be too controlling and give you no freedom in sections. At other times, they are non-existent to ask logistical questions and the like.

review_title: Good place to do some research over the summer
job_title: Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
-Easy to get some research experience in engineering over the summer
-The professors who lead the research are usually (2/3 in my experience) accessible
-Learn and get paid
cons:
-Sometimes get stuck doing rote tasks; can be repetitive
-1/3 professors was too self-loving (the other two were modest though)

review_title: A great place to work if you want to do academic work.
job_title: App Programmer/Analyst Intermediate in Seattle, WA
pros:
Great PTO and sick time policies.
Depending on your team great work culture
Deliverables tended to be very attainable.
cons:
When dealing with the university, you may run into a surprising amount of bureaucracy when dealing with minor or trivial matters.
It was a very operational infrastructure and as a result building new product is generally seen as a cost center.

job_title: Data Science Research Analyst in Dearborn, MI
pros:
1. Great labs
2. Promising research opportunities and/or projects
3. I got a raise 3 times during the course of a year and 8 months
4. Very supportive staff and faculty members
cons:
This is totally based on the Professor you're working with ..

1. Legally supposed to work 20 hours per week, however, I was working close to 40 hours with no overtime compensations ..
2. I was forced to do things last minute because of my Professor's very busy schedule ..

review_title: A great place to train for future opportunities
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The resources for research are incomparable in the mid-west region. While administration can vary from one department to the next, I was fortunate to have great support from my department (I was in one of the many programs under the medical school).
cons: There can be a lack of consistency in handling administrative issues across departments/units. My department (under the medical school) was prompt in issues regarding benefits, compensations, and so forth. This might take a while for external approval, or getting cheques mailed, etc.

review_title: Willing to Sacrifice a Good Education for Money
job_title: Undergraduate Student in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Lots of staff and resources for students to use
Many clubs and extracurricular activities
Lots of classes with exceptional professors
Great location in Ann Arbor
Beautiful campus
Lots of places to study
cons: The administration put students health at risk by encouraging students to come back to campus and even though 72% of classes are online, they decided to raise tuition instead of discount it. A very poor COVID 19 response.

review_title: Excellent place with very good benefits
job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: High pressure and creative environment. Excellent bennefits: Best health benefits I know of and retirement consists of a 5% employee contribution + 2:1 employer match  for 15% into 403b.
cons: Salary for position is low compared to what is available in industry. Your experience will depend on supervisor and some managers (professors) are very difficult to deal with while others are great

job_title: Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Awesome people, there are absolutely the most awesome people at this place.  Truly incouragible with absolutely no regard for conventionality.  heck yes i love this school.
cons: Low Salary, honestly i didnt even know if I was getting paid because it was electronic deposits and it never seemed like my bank account had anything in it.  a contributing factor to this phenomenon may also have been poor spending habits but thats outside the realm of this conversation

job_title: Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: It's amazing as an undergraduate to have research experience with top scholars in your field. I benefitted from that and the opportunity to develop personal relationships with research scientists.
cons: My research work was unstructured by my research mentor. This allowed for a lot of freedom, but also made my tasks seem directionless. Sometimes, it was research for the sake of research.

job_title: Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Excellent research environment, good resources, good opportunities for collaboration.
cons: Dangerously incompetent HR/Benefits department, benefits are bad regardless of the terrible administration, 'my-way-or-the-highway' attitude (aka, FIFO; Fit in or faff off!), UMHS is authoritarian in its demands from employees.

job_title: Grader in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Part time student jobs are very easy to find and apply to at U-M. Flexible hours can typically be negotiated for most Grader positions since we don’t have to attend class. Lots of great tech tools can make grading easier too.
cons: Get your part time jobs in early if you’re a Bachelor’s/Master’s student. Employment is a staircase here, you need grader experience to be accepted as a GSI typically because usually those positions go to PhD students. Can’t think of any other cons really. I enjoyed my experience working here!

review_title: Great place to work; poor management
job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The students are very inspiring.  The resources are plentiful, even when there are budget cutbacks.  The campus is beautiful.  The faculty are top notch.
cons: The organization is poorly managed and the communication channels are closed shut between units.  Proactive communication is discouraged and often the unit that is being affect by a change is the last to know.

review_title: University of Michigan is a great employer
job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: U/M keeps us informed of the institution standings, financial, etc.  We are too large for me to have a 'loud' voice but I know my contributions are for the greater good, particularly the patients and families that come here.  It's nice to be a part of something that I can make a difference.
cons: Sometimes to large to be able to feed information to executive leadership

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Awesome department! Very close knit. Graduate student community is great. Professors care about their research, want you to really learn. Plenty of opportunities to volunteer, try teaching, tons of amazing research opportunities. And the pay/benefits are really some of the best around.
cons: Most likely nature of the field, but seems to be a little insular and not very diverse. Professors need to hire more females. Professors need to be more active at nominating their students for awards (have too many absent-minded moments).

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: UM really does have some of the best researchers in the world to train with.
cons: As a post-doc, there are limited options to grow within the university post training.  Very few tenure track positions and associate scientists position are a bit of a no-man's land in terms of job growth.

job_title: Community Assistance in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Loved a lot of the students I was on staff with, some were very passionate and truly wanted to help residents.
cons: LT (long term staff) was utterly incompetent for the most part. It's different for different dorms (I was in East Quadrangle) but there is a culture of hypersensitivity and red tape. Claims that ResStaff is there to provide a better experience for residents is an absolute lie. ResStaff is there because housing is a liability issue.

review_title: You must repeatedly ask people for less and less money until they hang up on you, or you get fired.
job_title: Telefund Caller in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: You talk to some interesting alumni for 5-7 minutes before you have to start bothering them for money.
cons: You must pester and manipulate people for money. You must be able to handle repeated verbal rejection and criticism.

job_title: Graduate Student in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: University of Michigan has a great reputation and great microscopy equipment within the college of engineering and the materials science and engineering programs. Both of these things put you a cut above from the get go
cons: Many of University of Michigans best faculty are getting stolen by other schools trying to increase there reputation, which is a bummer for the program.

review_title: Generally good place to be a postdoc
job_title: Postdoctoral Assistant Professor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Good benefits thanks to strong graduate student union. Ann Arbor is overall a nice place to live. U of M has a good academic reputation but quality of mentoring and research experience will vary a lot by department and research area within a department. I had a good working group and fantastic mentor.
cons: Very little diversity, at the U and in Ann Arbor. University is very profit driven and the deans and leadership are clearly making bank and only looking out for themselves

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: University of Michigan is a good University with a good reputation.  More resources and funding available than most other places, and this means more opportunities.  Lots of very smart people here to work with.
cons: Not sure.  I don't like dwelling on the negative.  It is annoying when they hire idiots who think they are smart, and you have to work with them.

job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Exciting work, amazing colleagues, great support staff. Benefits package is really incredible. Ability to pretty much dictate your own working hours as a researcher.
cons: Limited town size hurts personal growth. Constantly having to a chase grant money. Salaries are good by university standards, but not great by industry standards. The particulars of my job make the work pretty isolating, so it can be difficult to feel socially "connected" on a day-to-day level. Lack of implementation of ideas can be frustrating, but I'm most in theory.

review_title: A public university slowly becoming a private enterprise
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Excellent benefits, access to expertise in a variety of fields, and competitive pay.
cons: Too much focus on the growth of the endowment and student body, with less emphasis on quality of education. The College of Engineering is trending toward an entrepreneur/startup-driven culture (ala Stanford) which really does not seem to be in line with the purpose of a public university. Overall, much more conservative than the common perception of Ann Arbor might imply.

job_title: Project Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great facilities, world-class faculty, and strong commitment to excellence. Overall a great academic setting. You get a real sense of competitiveness in a good way.
cons: Weather isn't awesome. Teaching is great but, you tend to get a lot of children whom have little desire to be at the school. Zero office culture, most employees rarely meet up away from work. You can tell at times, the tenure pressure gets to many young faculty more than it should.

review_title: Great people, lots of red tape
job_title: Media Analyst in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I loved working with the people in my department. They were smart and open to hearing ideas from younger staff members. It was part-time, but the hours were flexible.
cons: It was hard to always get things done or move up. There always seemed to be a line up of people that needed to approve something before anything got there. No real room for growth and it was easy to get stuck in your position.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: There are so many resources that I will miss when it is time to leave; the graduate library, statistical consulting, the writing center, NOURISH, etc. Most people are willing to help when it is needed.
cons: Apart from the weather :), my experience here has been pretty positive so far. I would say it is a pretty intense environment so if you don't do great with stressful situations, this is probably not the place for you.

job_title: in Deerfield, MI
pros: Provides an environment with many opportunities for learning and meeting new people. Ability to move around to different areas of employment within because of the large size.
cons: Large size makes employees sometimes just feel like a number within the system. Sometimes tough to find the correct contact information for specific supervisors because of the size of the place.

job_title: Applications Development Technical Specialist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Lots of room to develop due to the incredible amount and breadth of resources available throughout the university in their multiple department and colleges.
cons: Huge amount of organization inertia and BS needed to overcome in order to make progress. The politics are also very real, and must be minded in order to progress your work.

job_title: Assistant Coach in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great atmosphere and competitive pay.  Exciting events taking place on a regular basis.  Pro sport environment.  Great weather in the spring summer and fall.  Great town with awesome food and night life.
cons: Work life balance is awful.  Liberal brainwashing runs rampant on that campus.  Extremely dark long winter puts a strain on mental health.

job_title: Clinical Subjects Coordinator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The patients and physicians are wonderful. It is truly a collaborative team effort. There are many research trials that come through the OCTSU.
cons: The OCTSU is one of the most disorganized and incompetent places I've worked at. Management is out of touch with the responsibilities of their employees, they overwork and underpay every one of us. There is a new career ladder coming out that does not make sense for what we do, either. Management consists of staff that don't know what they are actually managing. Avoid if you can.

review_title: A comfortable environment to work in
job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
1) Excellent work/life balance: there is no push to work long hours
2) Supervisors are happy to support requests for tuition reimbursement
3) Once hired, there are many opportunities to move within the University
cons:
1) The university is extremely decentralized, making many attempts at change nearly impossible because of the number of potential veto-points
2) The pay is not great

review_title: Survey Technician at the Institute for Social Research
job_title: Survey Technician in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
-Working at UM gets you an MCard which allows you to ride the Ann Arbor buses for free - makes up for the fact that parking is hard to find.
-Nice, helpful management.
-Cash bonuses are a nice incentive for meeting monthly goals.
cons:
-Free parking on the street is hard to find, but I wouldn't overly blame the Univ. of Michigan for that one. 
-Part-time job with only  4 - 6 hour shifts doesn't make this a real money maker.

review_title: A company that takes care of its employees and the community.
job_title: Reference Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: You can continue your education while working, you have flexible work time, you are surrounded by intelligent people that care about the University as an institution as well as a place of learning
cons: It can get very cold in the long winters, and trying to get around Ann Arbor during game days is basically impossible. There are many different departments within the University, and it can get confusing as to how to go about getting things done.

job_title: Research Specialist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Employer is generally willing to work around classes for students
Office culture varies, but where I worked was very relaxed
Lots of potential areas to specialize in
cons:
Compensation was a little low in comparison with my experiences other places
There wasn't much potential for upward mobility, especially without a Masters or PhD
There tends to be a somewhat high turnover rate, but that's not unusual in a University setting

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: This is a top-notch, globally recognized scholarly institution that has flexible hours and promotes critical thinking, hard work, and a sense of community.
cons: There are no clear cons to this institution. Perhaps, if academia or the academic setting is not of interest, this would be a touch institution to appreciate.

job_title: Early Childhood Educator in University Center, MI
pros: Staff, environment, benefits, teacher to child ratio, playground, field trips, feeling of support from parents, opportunity for nanny gigs outside of work
cons: Stressful working with children at times, didn't always get my desired pay, lunch break, or classroom, didn't feel I was able to use my full skills as a teacher

review_title: Enjoyable environment when you make friends
job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Opportunity for promotion, busy environment, mostly friendly staff, at the heart of the city, many services and events go on daily, many people to meet
cons: low starting pay, history of corruption within management, sometimes difficult people to work with, older co-workers act like children at times

job_title: Office Assistant in Dearborn, MI
pros:
- Lost of opportunities to expand your skillset by working with many professors on specific tasks.
- Flexible hours (up to 25 a week)
- relaxed work environment
- free coffee!
cons:
- Many layers of management which lead to role conflict.
- Tasks are often ad hoc which means there is a lot of thinking on the fly (could be a pro)
- expectations are often improperly set

job_title: IT Consultant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Decent pay for student work, great relationships between coworkers, good benefits for full time workers, customers are generally easy to work with, and scheduling was amenable to classes or a second job.
cons: There is very little chance that you can stay in these positions and next to no growth.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great advisor and collegues. challenging and exciting work. Gained several new technical skills. flexible work schedule. Good pay and course credit
cons: at first, i was required to do my work in the computer lab because my computer didn't have all of the software. Then i received the software for free, so in the end, i could do the work in my dorm

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Welcoming academic atmosphere, flexible part-time schedule, and fair pay.  Colleagues were eager to help new employees adjust to a learning curve and seemed to welcome input from all team members, regardless of stature within the organization.
cons: Opportunities to advance within my department (research based) were understandably limited. Variation in day to day work was minimal, making things a bit stale after a while.

review_title: Its a best learning place if you are a graduate or an undergraduate student
job_title: Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: You can get yourself recognized very easily
cons:
Not an extraordinary place to do postdoc, as they dont hire their own postdoc for faculty position, so you would end up looking for job at orher University that would be ranked lower than U of M
Salaries are among the lowest for postdoc category

job_title: Software Engineer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Depending on who you work for, your position will provide you flexible hours.  The benefits are excellent.  There are a lot of research-related positions where the work is very interesting.  Raises are consistent and usually department-wide.
cons: Non-academic, development or research positions means limited room for advancement.  For most positions, you're pretty much limited to the position you are hired to, unless you apply to another department.  This may not apply to all types of positions.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great benefits, especially vacation and the retirement match. Easy access to some world-class academic facilities and hospital resources. Ann Arbor is a great town, and a very nice place to live.
cons: Slow advancement (low turnover). Low salaries for junior staff. Ann Arbor is very cosmopolitan for its size, but if you want the big city, it's not here.

review_title: AMAZING, amazing benefits and retirement - wonderful atmosphere
job_title: Producer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great schedule, great vacation days, college town and atmosphere, went somewhat in line with collegiate calendar so awesome summers :-)
cons: In the position I was in, there was virtually no career ladder. Within three years, three of the four person team I was on have moved on to other opportunities or even moved out of state.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bad Axe, MI
pros: Strong academic program with focus on individuals growth potential in a large multi disciplinary medical program. Very strong teaching opportunities for both novice and experienced faculty.
cons: Not many cons to report from working with some of the best minds in medicine. As a large institution there are times when it can seem that the individual is lost within the bigger system.

job_title: Sales Associate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Training can be good for being ready in your first week of work, and Company Culture is great and welcoming for you to transition from a newcomer to member of the family.
cons: Leadership can be micro managers, even when work is completed, to the point you have to make it a skill to look busy in most times they are on "patrol".

job_title: Clinical Assistant Professor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Well organized program, very receptive to feedback. Great work-life balance due to well balanced system with an emphasis on academics in addition to patient care. Very well supported clinically and a great hospital system to work within.
cons: New faculty may have difficulty accessing teaching opportunities including wards time. Academic time with FTE is difficult to obtain unless you are already established in the educational or research group here.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
- Very flexible work hours
- Typically friendly colleagues
cons: Depending on your school and/or department, there is a high degree of variability in terms of management training and professionalism. I had an incredibly unprofessional boss, who was emotionally manipulative. However, there was no HR support for me to seek counseling and/or ameliorate the situation. I ended up leaving the role because it was the only way to escape this miserable boss.

job_title: Program Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Positive Atmosphere with hardworking colleagues who take the time to think through solutions and to make changes.  Good colleagues who are sincerely focused on making a difference in the lives of students. Great benefits and accommodations.
cons: Pay could be better.  Although there are a huge number of resources, some of the resources for students are hard to access especially from campus to the hospital.

review_title: Awful, Upper managment does not come through on anything they promise.
job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Better pay than most yay.
cons: I was granted a leave of absence because I suddenly fell ill and stayed ill.  I was granted this by two seperate doctors and my supervisors okayed this.  However U of M had a doctor who HAD NEVER EXAMINED ME OR SEEN ME BEFORE say that I was okay to come back to work.  However I was in Ohio at another hospital trying to figure out what was wrong with me.  Why Ohio and now U of M....because the U of M health system is a joke.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The work environment is a generally collegial type of atmosphere.  People have less tendency to be self-interested when there is no focus on profit.  The benefits are great, with a generous retirement plan, vacation time, and health benefits.
cons: The decentralized structure of the higher education environment makes it difficult to get things done sometimes, particularly when processes are involved that require standardization.  Also, people who work in higher education are  sometimes unrealistic about the importance of policies and procedures.

review_title: It is your choice - depends on what you like
job_title: Retired in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Wonderful co-workers, except the administration; nice environment; clean campus; great benefits; safe haven for gays and lesbians; access to many libraries; "big brother" keeps an eye on what you are doing on the Internet, so you are safe.
