cons: Horrendous, huge-and-bulging incompetent administration; no growth except for lick-spittle; you are always wrong if your opinion differs from the management, and you will be framed and punished if you try to prove your case; double standard for different race; undeniable support and preference to liberals even if they are liars.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fraser, MI
pros: ITS is a big group at UM but worked with a small team ~6 to manage all campus computer sites and repair machines.
cons: UM has a huge number of students ~40K and plenty of huge computer sites which is a lot sometimes for a such a small team to take care of. There are other teams that deal with bringing machines in and out as well as onsite trouble shooting. But when they have problems the come to us.

job_title: Student Food Service Worker in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
I worked at Mojo dinning hall. I loved that you were able to pick your own schedule at the beginning of the semester and then have it set. You could easily pick up shifts and get others to cover yours. 

There are A & B week schedules. I usually just picked up the same shifts for both A & B  week to make it easy to remember.
cons: You have to work a closing shift during either A or B week.

review_title: UM is top-notch from facilities & equipment to faculty, staff, and students.
job_title: Research Technician Associate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
The UM community is open, diverse, and collaborative. There are many core facilities and support services including health & safety that promote ethical, robust, and translational research. 

The transportation services are useful for traveling between the various campuses.
cons: The only downside that I have experienced is the expense of parking and the traffic from construction that leads to longer than expected commute times. It is manageable during off rush hour times.

job_title: Information Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Fantastic management, made meeting enjoyable. Always open to feedback and to adjusting the way the system works. Great location of campus, and a great way to meet people.
cons: Paid close to minimum wage (but this is understandable since it is mostly a student job and we are often free to work on other things when on the job if it's not busy)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Low pressure. Plenty of time to improve yourself. The client I did the project for is quite generous and have almost time limit. I can work at my own pace to get everything perfect and learn a lot from them.
cons: For some people it may be a little bit boring because of the slow pace. It really depends on what kind of job you want.

job_title: Field Interviewer in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
This position uses most of my skills as an  office worker along with interviewing
and person to person skills as well as telephone and  data entry and Customer
Service experience.  I worked with University of Michigan closer to 17 but your list doesn't go below 2014,
cons: Working with the public  and visiting them at home can provide a challenge at times.

job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Challenging work
Competent peers
Lots of room to build technical experience 
Access to training to engineering machines like lathes and mills
Research materials
cons:
Longer hours than originally anticipated
Little to no praise for new team members from management/professors
If you are looking for a internship  that offers lots of money, then Michigan would not be the place to look.

review_title: I felt well supported in my position and able to use my own innovation and leadership.
job_title: Research Specialist Associate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Hospital system is well-funded so there is flexibility in programming.
The benefits package was excellent.
The UM community is global so you're always bound to meet a friendly alum or employee wherever you go.
cons:
Creating positions or instating truly innovative solutions takes a long-time.
As a decentralized institutions, people often recreate the wheel.

review_title: Great work/life balance, compensation is low.
job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Work with very intelligent people. Intellectually-stimulating environment. Exposure to academics and thought leaders through work and attendance at a variety of events. Easy to continue your education if you wish, take part in interest areas across campus.
cons: Patriarchal culture. Compensation half what I made in the private sector (lower is to be expected, but half is not sustainable long-term). I would rate the company much higher if staff salaries were more competitive. Bureaucratic, slow procedures.

review_title: good place to work and live
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: A good school with a nice surrounding area. The people are nice and there are many things to do in Ann Arbor. Graduate students get paid a fairly good stipend.
cons: The weather in the fall and summer is nice, but the winters are long and snowy/overcast. Otherwise no complaints.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: University of Michigan is a nice place to work and study. I'm a teaching assistant this term for a machine learning course and it helps me understand machine learning better.
cons: It takes some time to grade homework and record all the grades because it's a large class with more than 130 students.

job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The hours are very flexible. You schedule your own availability and are only scheduled within this time. The training and professional development is very helpful and is paid.
cons: The tutoring management system malfunctions frequently and scheduling can be difficult. The work can be overwhelming at times, especially because student's workloads tend to pick up when your personal workload picks up.

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: excellent benefits as a GSI at U of M. health care is exceptional and a lot is included in the plans including inclusion for a non-married partner. dental and optical add ons are reasonable.
cons: GSI appointments vary. some definitely require work over 20 hours a week, but overtime is cumbersome to come by. others are considerably under. overall this salary is very low given the educational background of GSIs (most with masters degrees pursuing PhDs), but is competitive among other schools.

job_title: Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Working within the University has allowed me to connect and establish relationships with not only my advanced colleagues within my laboratory, but also those within the department. After working with the university in many different positions over the years, they really do try to provide you with the best pay, environment, and benefits as possible.
cons: There have been a few instances where guidelines were not as clear as they should have been, leading to personal error (and retribution in result).

review_title: Good pay for faculty, mediocre pay for lecturers
job_title: Lecturer I in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Great school, expensive but clean/safe town, and generally low pay for lecturers and staff.
The student body is excellent and generally bright amd diverse.
cons: Such a big system can be overwhelming and feel impersonal. Pay for lecturers and staff is shockingly low for a university with $10B endowment

review_title: Great place to work, but bureaucracy challenging
job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great people, and good culture.  Benefits are also solid.  Ann Arbor is great too though, so the location is as good as it gets in Michigan.
cons: Can be very difficult to find right person for things and way to get things done.  Slow moving as well, typical for a university.

job_title: Recent Grad Initiative Intern in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great supervisor, great program and professional development component to the internship. Gave interns a lot of responsibility and room to grow
cons: Sometimes the work was a little overwhelming but welcome to the real world! Other than that there were no real cons. I had an amazing experience.

job_title: Media Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
My coworkers and the faculty I worked with were some of the most understanding and intelligent people I had ever met.

My supervisors were flexible as I was a student and they took care of me
cons: My position was temporary which meant that I did not receive any benefits

job_title: Caller in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I really enjoyed working at the University of Michigan, a college located in Michigan. Overall, it was a positive experience.
cons: There were some things that I didn't enjoy about working at the University of Michigan, a college in Michigan. Overall, a few things could be changed.

job_title: Grasuate Student Instructor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: If you find a professor who treats graduate students fairly, being a graduate student instructor might be a very good source of income during the Ph.D.
cons: There are not enough assistantship positions. The salary is low and does not cover the summer. Workload might be high with some professors.

review_title: An overall excellent university for engineering students
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
1. Good academic environment for researchers
2. Students are hardworking, which provides a good environment for learning skills
3. Some courses are so good that no other universities can provide
cons:
1. Some good courses do not have enough good professors. Students may feel that some important courses are taught by professors who do not really understand the course materials
2. Most of the courses are in big classes.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Working in an intellectual environment with friendly people is the most advantage of working here. In terms of research, you can find great collaborations and equipment.
cons: Winter in Michigan is really tough. There are not many things to do in your free time in the winter. If you are not used to live in cold climate, it's one thing that you need to consider. Also, if you are from big city, it's small town, so you should lower your expectations.

job_title: Research Investigator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Ann arbor is a nice and quiet town. People here are very nice and polite to stranger. But young faculties keep moving to other university for better promotion.
cons: the pay is low compare to other places or institutes. parking was not enough for the work days. If you are lucky, you might find a spot near your work place, or you will try to find a parking spot all the way around and then park far far away.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: In general, this is a great research institution with a lot of resources in the College of Engineering where I am a student.
cons: I have heard engineering students complain about Michigan focusing on research rather than teaching. In that case, therefore, it would not be disappointing sometimes when classes are not really taught well.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: You have many resources and I was able to establish many internal collaborations, in order to accomplish my project.
cons: I was confronted with a very unethical situation in my medical research and I said NO. It was a painful period and at a certain point I decided to leave because I had no choices. And I had to negotiate with NIH by myself.

job_title: Software Developer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Work as a software developer for the university of michigan as an undergrad student. Job is very low demand and gives me a great balance of being a student and work part time at the same time.
cons: I have enjoyed my experience so far. There is nothing that I find a con. Great development experience as an undergrad.

job_title: Assistant Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Awesome benefits.  Some really great people.  Supportive community of like-minded people.  Opportunities to learn a lot about multiple aspects of running a business.
cons: Recent FLSA decision to not give pay raises to exempt staff, after telling exempt staff that they would receive pay raises.  Action pending on that.

job_title: PhD Student in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: University of Michigan has a top 10 department in nearly every field, so there is always a brilliant professor in your field of choice.
cons: Depending on the research group you choose, the PhD program could take anywhere from 5 to 8 years.  So asking how long it takes until graduation is critical.

review_title: Collaborative research environment and high quality training
job_title: Ph D Candidate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Collaborative and supportive research environment
Many high quality faculty and labs across a wide range of disciplines 
Ph.D. training programs can vary significantly based on department, but all seem to provide great training and opportunites
cons: Ann Arbor is a cute town and a nice place to live and work, but there are fewer jobs here compared to larger cities. It's not a viable place to live long-term once you graduate for that reason.

job_title: Research Development Analyst in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Salary and benefits are great.
cons:
The Development Department is extremely siloed and hierarchical.  If you're looking to innovate and jump in to get your hands dirty, don't go to U-M.  It takes years for change to happen and get approved, and most employees sit with their feet on the desk looking through Facebook while they wait.  You will not be supported for any creativity or innovative efforts.  Cliques abound in the prospect development and analytics department.

The University used to care about its employees, but now it's much more focused on money, saving it and making it.  It's far less about education.

review_title: Generally good, ok pay, great benefits.
job_title: Programmer Analyst in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Flexible hours
Generally hands off management (for my job)
Highly intellectually stimulating
Great co-workers
cons:
Researchers who lead big projects need to learn how to manage people and teams
IT support work can vary a lot in degree of pain (e.g. non-existent or inappropriate resource to accomplish goals)
Lack of leadership leads to continual doubt about priorities, expectations and so on

review_title: As a research fellow at the University of Michigan I have taken my career farther than I thought possible.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The facilities and personnel are among the best I've ever associated with and most everyone that I have worked with is willing to help you to succeed.
cons: Since there is a clear importance to produce consistent, high-quality science (both in terms of data and publications) there is associated stress and work/life balance questions that you will need to deal with.

job_title: Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Ann Arbor is a wonderful and vibrant town, there is a liberal atmosphere, and there are lots of people from different backgrounds and interests here. Furthermore, at the workplace, people are collaborative, friendly, and smart, which all lead to greater team efforts.
cons: The weather here is generally cold or too warm. The cost of living here is on the higher end in terms of food compared to towns of similar sizes in different parts of the Midwest.

job_title: Senior SQL Server Database Administrator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The location is convenient, and most of the people are very nice.
cons: I worked in the hospital side of the university, so the systems I supported had to be up 99.999% of the time.  Almost all maintenance had to be done in the middle of the night on a weekend.

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: This is an organization that is quite large since it includes the university and the hospital so you have a chance to advance within the organization quite easily.  The benefits are great and because the UofM is so large, it offers a great deal of in-house training and learning opportunities.
cons: No matter how good you are, it is very unlikely you will see anything more than a cost of living raise unless you change positions.

job_title: GSRA in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Flexible time, diverse background, top-class research, smart people all around, good entrepreneurship spirits, beautiful campus, awesome football team, good food in the city
cons: This is a very nice university with really nice faculty and staff. I can think of no cons in this university. If there is, it must be that it is not the best from the perspective of ranks, say US news.

job_title: PhD Student in Detroit, MI
pros: great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great great
cons: there is nothing to complain about. Great place for a phd. Just want to start my career earlier so that I could save time to enjoy life.

job_title: Registered Dental Hygienist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: University of Michigan is a great place to work. They are very family friendly and employee oriented. Their benefits are excellent.
cons: Because they are such a big employer some of the policy may be difficult to understand if you are coming to work for them from a more privately owned business. The policies in place are necessary to protect the University as a whole so that it can continue to provide an excellent workplace to its employees.

review_title: Post-doctoral research fellow, Materials Science and Engineering
job_title: Post Doctoral Research Fellow in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
- great lab and collaborative working environment
- respected institution with emphasis on publishing research results
- good resources for post-docs on how to further their careers in academia or industry
cons:
- professors can be hard to reach at times
- separation between north and central campus research facilities
- not much support on how to obtain grant funding

review_title: Worst IT management I ever encountered.
job_title: Programmer Analyst in Dearborn, MI
pros: Vacation, health benefits and 401(k) is generous.
cons:
Management does not give feedback or set expectations but still finds employees at fault. Management lack people skills and rely on bullying, intimidation and condescension behind closed doors. Lack of onboarding and training for new employees. Management is also willing to throw employees under the bus instead of standing up for and protecting the team.

Overall technology landscape is also outdated and culture is very poor. Most of mangement efforts seems to be in playing political games, especially who to blame.

review_title: Great benefits and work/life balance, but poor leadership
job_title: Program Coordinator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Health and retirement benefits are insanely good, and most student services jobs at the university are relatively low-stress and laidback.
cons: There doesn't seem to be much leadership training for managers, so many units suffer from toxic supervisors. It's also very difficult to move up within a given unit/department since there are many "lifers" sitting in their jobs awaiting retirement. The only way to get ahead is to move from department to department.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant and Graduate Student Instructor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great place to work and study; balance your family/business life; lots of social events going on any time of the year.
cons: If you are not used to long hours of work in the lab, even during the weekends and nites, it might be a little challenging. Well, who said being a grad student is easy?

review_title: Probably more good than bad; everything dependent on which department you work in.
job_title: Physician Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Good benefits, great onsite CME opportunities (if your department supports PA attendance) & overall good resourses to provide quality care.  Quality nursing & support staff on day shift.
cons: Many departments/sections do not utilize PAs/NPs to full capabilities.  Parking is expensive & not convenient - plan an extra 30 minutes to get from car to job site & vice versa.  Poorly staffed on off shifts.

review_title: A great place to work and live
job_title: Facilities in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: They have competitive pay, and the people in Ann Arbor are great for the most part. My hours were flexible, and they were willing to work with my schedule
cons: I honestly have no complaints about working here, The only thing that could be close to a complaint is that my pay did not increase. But that wasn't too bad do a problem because my starting pay was good

job_title: Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Working at the University provides you with a sense of community and pride, however that can only take you so far.
cons: The University's hiring practices leave much to be desired.  They often tend to hire from within and provide candidates with little to no communication.  I attempted to change this from within but it was always an uphill battle.

review_title: UofM North Quad: Great people, great work, awesome community.  It'll be hard to top working here."
job_title: Media Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
- Very nice people, almost across the board
- Awesome facilities (I work in North Quad)
- Very flexible
- Access to North Quad resources
cons:
- Communication between departments isn't great and can often result in frustration
- Big university bureaucracy (hard to escape that)

job_title: in Livonia, MI
pros: If you enjoy being overworked and forced to provide more QUANTITY care than QUALITY care to your patients, being constantly harassed by superiors and lied to - then this is just the right place for you.
cons: Work environment is stressful, people constantly fighting IN FRONT of patients because the stress level is so high due to over working them and the constant battle of trying to get one another fired. It is absolutely sickening.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great environment to work with brilliant students and outstanding faculty and staff. Great alumni network. Most areas are well funded. Very progressive university.
cons: Very large university, may have become to large. Inequality in resources among departments (think Ross School of Business vs School of Education).

review_title: Nuclear medicine department is very compartmental. Too many cliques and back stabbing.
job_title: Nuclear Medicine Technologist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The benefits and vacation plan is exceptional. Health care is centered around patients and families.  Top notch facilities and equipment.
cons: Parking is horrific.  Work life balance does not exist for our department. Call is long... Friday night to Monday morning. Covered by one person.

job_title: Audiovisual Technician in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Coworkers and colleagues are outgoing and friendly
Benefits and costs are amazing
cons:
Politically charged atmosphere among coworkers due to competition for raises/position changes/title adjustments due to  the university's lack of funding for staff

Not able to progress to a better position within your department

Hectic hours 

Extremely low wages and high cost of living

Must pay for parking out of pocket which runs about $1700 a year if you want to be close to campus

review_title: #1 department in the country, and great place to work
job_title: Otolaryngologist in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Large department, great new leadership in the department,
Great resident trainees
Faculty are open, friendly, and staff are top notch
cons: The reorganization of the ambulatory care group is taking a long time, so changes are hard to implement

job_title: Office Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: This was a work study job and the department I worked at was very welcoming. Everyone was friendly and the job wasn't too bad.
cons: I did the typical work-study tasks, photocopying, delivering mail, and other various tasks that needed to be done. It wasn't too bad but could get a bit tedious.

job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Get exposure to every discipline of academics you can think of, and an extremely wide variety of quality cultural events. Summer and fall here is also breath taking.
cons: Snowy weather in 5-month winter is a big minus. Also things are slow because of bureaucracy of a public university sometimes, compared to the coastal areas.

job_title: Pension Analyst in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Extremely intelligent and interested coworkers. Laid back atmosphere but there is a firm direction in place as well as a ton of patience for teaching someone new to the job (such as myself). Very flexible as far as hours go and a large emphasis on skill development and taking your own initiative for greater responsibility.
cons: I have yet to experience any negative aspects in my time working at the University of Michigan as of the current date.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Dearborn, MI
pros: Research interesting stuff which you might want to continue in your PhD and get some income for living
cons: Using too much time on research may not be perfect if you want to start work after graduation.

job_title: Graduate Assistant Coach in Norwalk, CA
pros: Great University to work for and definitely a resume builder. Management is caring and willing to help. People and co workers are friendly.
cons: Extremely long work hours.  Has a lot of red tape to get certain things done. This may seem fickle but being from California the weather could be an impediment.

job_title: in Houston, TX
pros: A pretty great place to work. Good benefits, though I didn't really take advantage of them. Ann Arbor is a great town.
cons: Not a whole lot of cons. Like any big organization there's a lot of bureaucracy, but nothing that is out of the ordinary.

job_title: PhD Student in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Umich has great professors, great courses. Umich has many many disciplines. You can definitely find one you like. Ann Arbor is also a good place to study and live.
cons: The only thing I can think is that the winter is too cold and too long in Ann Arbor. But I have already get used to that.

review_title: Low pay, great benefits, very variable depending on who you work under
job_title: Research Laboratory Technician Associate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The benefits are really great.  Ann Arbor is a nice place to live.  I've heard that once you have a job at U of M it's difficult to lose it without extreme cause for termination.
cons: The pay is under the average median, increases are minimal.  There are a lot of politics.  Technicians are grunts.

review_title: Overall - a great place to work.
job_title: Program Coordinator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Wonderful benefits, good paid leave policy
cons: Classification system is not appropriate for all positions and there are little options for those that don't ft the pre-set classifications and who seek advancement.

review_title: I enjoyed my time working here.
job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The working environment is comfortable. Have a lot of freedom in doing my own research, but need to be highly-disciplined. There is minimal supervision in how to conduct my work. Good for people who know what they like to do, and can do a good job by themselves.
cons: Maybe it's my personal (biased) feeling, but I would prefer more interactions with colleagues. I sometimes feel this place is pretty quiet.

review_title: The best place you can find in the State of Michigan
job_title: Graduate Student in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Ann Arbor is a lovely town, and working with the University of Michigan is a well-compensated and steady job that you can get.
cons: The sluggish Michigan economy doesn't provide a lot opportunities for the students and other staff for career development locally, unfortunately.

job_title: Graduate Student in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: At UM, I was surrounded by smart and helpful people. Everyone was very nice and accommodating. It's a very cozy environment.
cons: Ann Arbor is a little small, and the diversity is not what you'd get at a medium or large city. As a result, I had some trouble finding dynamic people.

job_title: Technical Analyst Associate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The medical benefits are outstanding! The retirement matching is off the charts! All of the people I worked with were wonderful. All levels of management are accessible.
cons: The pay, at least starting out, is not the best. I would say for a given job title, they pay below average to average. And there are a lot of layers, lot of stake holders, lots of meetings. Not exactly a fast moving, dynamic environment.

review_title: Student Graphic Designer - Unions Auxiliary Marketing
job_title: Graphic Designer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
Flexible hours - management understands that we are all students and our schedules get hectic
Real experience working with and collaborating with clients
Great way to get experience before entering the "real world." I've worked with every kind of medium, from banners to newsletters to branding campaigns.
Manager is well connected through alumni network.
cons: Hours are limited to office hours, 8-5 M-F, which can be hard to leave room for as a student.

review_title: Unbelievably low salary for a Ph.D. Mathematician with 16+ years of  job experience
job_title: CSP Mathematics Lecturer in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: In my opinion, this place has no pros.
cons:
Unbelievably low yearly salary of $35,448.75 for a Ph.D. Mathematician with 16+ years of experience teaching undergraduates all across the US with evidence of above average success which the university had access to at the time of hiring.

No travel fund for lecturers on one-year contracts to attend conferences to look for a more stable job for the following year even though they have no intention of re-hiring such lecturers.

review_title: Good for personal and career growth
job_title: Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: University of MIchigan not only pays well but the team that you get to work with come from diverse backgrounds who have a lot to offer.
cons: Considering that there a lot of people working at the University of Michigan, the place can get too crowded at times.

review_title: Review of the Resident Adviser Position
job_title: Resident Adviser in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
- Easy.
- Free room and board.
- Hanging out with residents can be a really good time, so the work can be really fun.
- Really easy.
- A lot of people on staff are nice and interesting.
cons:
- Viewpoints that aren't aligned with the UMich Housing philosophy are highly discouraged/suppressed.
- Workload and culture varies hugely from residence hall to residence hall.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Detroit, MI
pros: totally worth it. it was a good place to be and i'm grateful for the experience. it was a great experience and it will contribute to all

job_title: Student Coordinator in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The job has a great schedule. It is very flexible and easy to take off. Great people to work with and fun climate.
cons: Management promotes friends. Individuals who have worked harder then then do not get promoted as much. Also, some expectations are unreal.

job_title: Gsi in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great way to pay for you Ph.D. Help master basic material. Able to interact with young people, which is a plus during the isolating years of a Ph.D.
cons: Work was a little frustrating at times. Undergrads can be grade grubbers and sometimes expect everything to be given to them. Often times subject to the whims of the professor with little freedom to plan your discussion sections.

review_title: Excellent care of patients, not so much with employees
job_title: Lead Clerk in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great benefits, always something going on so you don't get bored, meet a lot of interesting people
cons: Parking is a hassle and you have to pay to park. Leadership is somewhat distant and hard to please. A lot of employees fighting for the top position

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
You get to be outside all day.
You work for one of the best Universities in the nation.
You get to learn a lot about horticulture.
cons:
You must be an early riser! 
You are working in all kind of conditions, which means hot, hot summer days in July.

job_title: Student Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
you can get SSN card and also make some money.
it's very easy to apply and to be trained. Staff are kind to you.
cons:
let you find how dirty and how clean a dish room will be.
some student manager is stupid.
you need to keep busy even there is actually nothing need doing

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI

cons: It's a smaller town. Work load can be high depending on program. in my department, in the engineering school, the campus is far away form downtown

job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great people to work with and under, Excellent place to learn widely applicable skills, Good hiring practices and will work closely with you to make sure you understand the job
cons: Sometimes a bit hectic but that is the nature of the job, Fairly low pay but no applicable experience required

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Good benefits and PTO, lots of hiring from within, great campus. Tons of intelligent people who care about their work.
cons: Personality politics, lots of narcissists in power positions. Married couples working on projects together can put support staff in awkward positions.

job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Excellent benefits:vacation & sick days on main campus, personal days on hospital campus; double-matching 403b
cons: Low salaries compared to the 'outside world'; not much room for advancement because people never leave because of the benefits; depending on where you work environment can range from hostile to easy-going

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
In general this is a great university. I have learned a lot during the time I'm here. The benefits are impressive. 
People are really friendly over here.
cons: The weather is not so well if you don't like the cold. Almost half of the year is snowing, and you can't really do anything during this time. It gets dark pretty early during winters, which greatly influenced my working efficiency.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: They match 401K 2-1. You accrue vacation time as soon as you are hired in. Benefits start right away.
cons: Parking is terrible. Parking passes are about $60 per month or more. Even if you do get a pass, there is nor guarantee that you will get a parking spot in some area's.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: No having to work holidays, less weekends, 2 to 1 matching retirement, dental, flex spend account, and good offerings of long term ad&d
cons: Health Insurance and vision insurance, life insurance not as good as old employer unless want to pay more

job_title: Statistician in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The university of Michigan has great work life balance.  They provide good benefits and the people are wonderful.  A great place to work.
cons: The employment process is a  bit slow.  There is always a lot of red tape to get things done.  If you are a grant funded position, there is always a little bit of nervousness about job stability.

review_title: System as a whole doesn't really care about retaining talent - unless you have a boss that does
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: State-of-the-art facilities allow for top-notch research and opportunities.  Also works closely with many top universities around the world.
cons: Perhaps because of its name, it doesn't really emphasize talent retention because they get a lot of it.  During my time there, I've seen many talented employees leave for other opportunities.

review_title: Great place to work, but not for a career in research
job_title: Research Associate Intermediate in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Awesome benefits, can make your own schedule if you're not afraid to ask you boss, relaxed atmosphere.
cons: Career trajectory. You will go nowhere in your career if this is what you're going to do. Incremental raises that don't keep up with inflation. HR manages raises, so your boss will not have final say on whether you get a merit raise or not.

review_title: Great school, great part time employment opportunities
job_title: Grader in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: It's hard to find a better place than Ann Arbor to live in the state of Michigan. The job paid well for a part time undergraduate student, and was easy to fit around my schedule.
cons: Sometime's its hard to get all of your assignments done quickly when school is at a tough point (i.e. have  large project due) but overall it is pretty easy.

job_title: Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Pay was quite good, compared to what many other places are offering. Hours were flexible. Working in Ann Arbor was great, as it is a fantastic city. Supervisor was fair and easy to communicate with.
cons: Although hours were flexible, there was a bit of pressure and a sense of urgency to meet deadlines for assignments. I was expected to remain available (via email, at least) outside normal work hours.

job_title: Building Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The entire time I worked there, I was met with friendly coworkers. They are very flexible on hours, and it is always a fun and exciting work environment.
cons: Usually had to work long night shifts. Weekend shifts were guaranteed. Occasional Holiday shifts.

job_title: Laboratory Technician in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great work environment. I really got to know my coworkers and their families. I miss them all very much.
cons: I sometimes felt swept under the rug. As a student employee you're sometimes seen as a fleeting body that isn't worth investing in long term. Had this case been otherwise I felt I would have stayed with the University after graduation.

job_title: Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: I have quite many opportunities to work with research faculties or staffs from many different areas so that I can have more chance to learn something useful for my research from them.
cons: You might be tired of writing proposals if you are the one who should have to get funding from outside of university.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Seattle, WA
pros: Get to make own schedule and meet new people; good compensation for mileage; frequent evaluations so you know what to improve
cons: Micromanagement at every turn; a ton of emails that one must respond to every day; management isn’t transparent about the hiring process or the conditions of employment

review_title: Lots of opportunity to learn from really smart people.

review_title: They try really hard to make everything very easy for you to get started.

review_title: GSI (Graduate Student Instructor). I was assisting professors in teaching two classes.

Being in close relationship with both students and professors, creating a bridge between the two.

job_title: Instructional Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: It's a good environment for research and study. You can develop the intellectual depth while sharpening your technical skill.
cons: The pay isn't very good. Also the politics in academia is much worse than people expected. If you would like to make money, do not try here

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Working as an undergraduate research assistant gave me valuable practical experience that I wasn't getting from my classes, which focused more on theory. Every engineer should participate in a research opportunity if the chance arises.
cons: Sometimes it was hard to get direction in the labs, as many there are focused on their own research.

review_title: This is specifically about the University of Michigan Center for Entrepreneurship department
job_title: Center for Entrepreneurship in Ann Arbor, MI
pros:
If you like entrepreneurship, this is a good way to get connected!
turnover is so high, you end up making so many friends and connections!
the students are great!
they're really big on birthdays!
no ones ever in the office so you can show up at 9:30 every day!
you'll learn creative ways and places you can cry on the job!
you develop DEEP friendships with the other coordinators suffering the reign of leadership!
cons:
Turnover is so high, in 2 years 70% of the staff has changed, however, they keep this under the radar by changing the title of the position they're trying to re-hire for every time. 
You'll be unpaid and undervalued unless you are a director.
All the directors are white men. All of them. There is nearly 0 diversity in leadership, but the CFE prides itself on diversity because all their assistants are women (yes, they missed the point).
so much casual racism, you begin to regress as a human. 
the director believes in reverse racism/sexism, so good luck trying to bring any diversity into your programs. 
if you're a coordinator, you will have no autonomy, no actual ownership over your programs, and your opinion is irrelevant. they just need someone who will be quiet and do the work. 
there's 0 professional development and a 0% chance you'll get a raise no matter how hard you work or how long you stay there. 
They blame their high turnover on "millennials" lol
There is 0 accountability when it comes to the directors. No direction, no vision. If you are not a director, you will have no say on any of the programs you run, and your opinion does not matter. 
If you are passionate about something they will try to stifle that passion.
this is NOT a place to grow your career, simply a stepping stone, but a very depressing one where you may develop depression and have to start seeing a therapist (not a joke :().
The HR person has no formal HR training and will casually scream at you and make you cry for simple mistakes. 
Crying in the office is common. 
You will have 0 autonomy and your calendar and every move will be studied, youll be asked to move your doctor appointments, you'll feel guilty for staying home sick, and god forbid you have a family death or an accident because the amount of emotional support or understanding you'll receive is MINIMAL. 
Your physical health will be affected by the job. I personally kept getting sick every 2-3 weeks.

job_title: in Ann Arbor, MI

1. you are in an academic setting.
2. Ann Arbor is a beautiful town -- great parks.
3. the University is huge
cons:
1. the University is very bureaucratic.
2. the place is very cold in winters
3. finding a place to live is a challenge

review_title: Great pay, awesome co-workers, and flexible hours.

review_title: Very good benefits. Great place to work.

review_title: Good Job to Make Some Money

review_title: Extremely talented colleagues, amazing projects, fantastic town!

review_title: Very nice people to work with

review_title: Stressful postdoctoral life style at EEB-UoM

job_title: Desktop Support Analyst in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Great location within walking distance of downtown Ann Arbor. Excellent hands on experience with many different technologies. Outstanding benefits.
cons: Lack of upward mobility. Very difficult to advance in the company unless you know or are related to someone in upper management. For a large scale company the pay does not match the job performance.

job_title: Research Assistant in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: quick growth, entrusted with a lot of responsibility, opportunity to work on multiple projects across the center, opportunity to get published
cons: the center really tries to pair up individuals and projects well. I would say the only con is that there comes a time when there can be a lull in the research, but that comes with any project you're working on.

review_title: Great research university; amazing opportunities for bright future!
job_title: Graduate Student in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Was a graduate student in physical sciences, had awesome health benefits, flexible work schedule, access to online libraries, facilities on campus open after hours, ...so many good things to list! Access to collaborators in other fields cannot be beat!
cons: pay is low for graduate students, long working hours, busy campus with so many students

review_title: Ross academic center tutor. Great job, great opportunity to meet new people.
job_title: Academic Tutor in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Decent pay, flexible hours, ability to make your own schedule, great leadership, opportunity to continue using past courses
cons: Sometimes students will either forget a lesson or will schedule last minute. This can sometimes make it tough to manage your own schedule.

job_title: Research Process Senior Manager in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: Highly collaborative environment, opportunities for professional development, faculty & student engagement, continual process improvement
cons: Limited opportunities to share ideas or implement radical changes, hard to engage mentorship, need for increased training on embracing diversity

review_title: This experience has been so fun to me
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The main reason I work here is to pay for college. I also love to meet new people on the job!
cons: Some of the challenges is that I have to work at night. You occasionally get tired throughout the day because of your messed up sleep cycle
